If you've got genuine New York gum stuck to the bottom of your shoe, chances are Dito Montiel wants to shoot it.
Like Crazy is an art-house romance about the pain and challenges of a long-distance relationship, and watching the film is itself a grueling exercise in yearning.
Across the board, Tim Chambers seems ignorant of what he's delivering, from the arc of his story to his choice of shot.
What results is something stylish, modern, nostalgic, cheesy, and more than a little Frankensteinian.
For a movie hellbent on marketing itself as the seedy tale of a small-town tramp, Dirty Girl sure has an odd way of making good on its promise.
This film could use a lot more affliction and a lot less cure.
Taylor Lautner can't carry a movie any more than Abigail Breslin can carry a refrigerator.
For what it's worth, Kate is Bradshaw in a blender: She still can't cook, but she's embraced the state of motherhood.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The estrogenic elements prove widely ineffectual, but they're just pieces of this overlong, overloaded misfire whose double-entendre title ultimately just goads the jaded viewer to admit defeat.
Of today's working directors, is there a bigger genre-swapping sellout than David Gordon Green?
Surely no one expected this movie to be masterful, as Streep has made it rather clear that she's not much interested in working with filmmakers whose talents might outshine her own.
Close never provides an entry point into the soul of this complex (and otherwise nameless) person, making it harder and harder to view the character as sympathetic.
Stephen Daldry abandons every lick of restraint in his efforts to play the audience like a syrup-greased harp.
The re-release is keenly timed with the 100th anniversary of the actual sinking of the RMS Titanic, yet another factor to validate the 3D film's existence.
Like Rodgers and Hammerstein's Cinderella with just a dash of Lars von Trier's Dogville, Tarsem Singh's rendering of this revisionist fairy tale is less cinematic than it is purposefully theatrical.
How to Survive a Plague presents a cast of characters who must continue fighting, for what's at stake is the very real, very imminent threat of their own deaths.
The adherence to a Grisham-like structure all but kills the film's chances of leaving a lasting impression.
The Hunger Games is more notable for the holes it doesn't fall into than the great heights it reaches.
Julia Murat shows a fine grasp of form, letting her technique reflect the elements and moods of her story.
movie_title: Historias que so existem quando lembradas (Found Memories) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: With the foul-mouthed, largely feminine dramedy Friends with Kids, writer/producer/director/star Jennifer Westfeldt is juggling so much, it's a wonder there aren't more jokes about balls.
At this point, Sparksian romances unfold via their own preordained formula, and measures of their merits largely hinge on how well each can bend the cookie-cutter.
If Robert De Niro knew what was good for him, he'd certainly distance himself from this director and find a new path.
This Means War seems so concerned with being the best product, it doesn't even know how to be good trash.
This is a movie whose true romance has virtually nothing to do with the movie itself.
Any goodwill it boasts is terminally suppressed, buried beneath a layer of bulls--- as thick as blubber.
You could go nuts with the double entendres associated with One for the Money, beginning, of course, with the film's title.
If anything, Haywire is most closely linked to last year's Contagion, a kindred effort in style, theme, and value-marring detachment.
Its kicker is that despite the standard-issue sap of its garden-variety plot, it's not out to change your life or desperately steal your tears.
Never are you really invested in any of this, as the movie is pervaded by lead-footed artificiality and the growing stink of crass marketing.
Nearly a year has passed since the release of Catherine Hardwicke's Red Riding Hood, and Amanda Seyfried is still crying wolf.
Küf's strongest elements may be its seemingly aimless subplots, which are essentially dismissed just as they're introduced, with minimal warning or explanation.
This epic waste of $190 million plunders the grab bag of overused plotlines, failing to put its own stamp on much of anything.
Its title, very graciously, doesn't end with a "Part 1," but The Host sure has enough plot points and ideas to fill two installments.
Its obsession with male genitalia, or, more specifically, penis receptacles, is emblematic of its overall aura of male entitlement and its consideration of women as prizes to be lanced.
Writer-director Ron Krauss's Gimme Shelter is wretched long before its odious ulterior motives come to light.
In keeping his actors on his sober-yet-buoyant plane, Kenneth Branagh presents a convincing romance that doesn't stall the film's brisk clip.
The film gradually reveals a lot of unsavory motives, which ultimately deflate the buoyant virtues on which the film had blithely coasted.
movie_title: The Adventurer: The Curse of the Midas Box (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A better film would have had the gumption to maintain the poetic bleakness, rather than steer toward what ultimately feels like safe compromise.
There's something vexing about the use of a baby as narrative device, and the movie leans too heavily on her inborn potential for heart-tuggery.
A once-precious franchise's weakest installment, which forgets these adventures' magic was never conjured by bells and whistles.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: What this movie finally boils down to is a deceptively simple tale of two brothers, and of being one's brother's keeper, and of seeking justice on the crudest of fronts.

Writer-director Will Slocombe preaches the values of laying resentments on the table, but with no true wisdom or novelty to offer, he's merely served an instantly forgettable slice of cinema de dysfunction.

A quasi-fairy-tale ending suggests the director and cowriter was content with shrugging her shoulders when it came to tying things up, but the knee-jerky close can't spoil the film's vibrant cultural and environmental specificity.
The film's empowering themes of feminine strengths and bonds eventually flourish in novel fashion.
Books themselves become the story's key symbol, representing the past and future, loss and possibility, of a place that's ground zero for some of history's darkest days.
Superhero movies aren't going anywhere, nor is their standard, on-to-the-next-fight structure, so it's heartening to see a gem that grandly and amusingly fills in the blanks.
[Establishes Reeves] as a deft helmer of cinematic combat ...
With its slow-burn pacing and horrifying reveals, Aftermath remains a deeply compelling puzzle.
Appreciation of the film lies, perhaps aptly, in the pieces built on a pillaged foundation.
Shana Feste's film seems blissfully unaware that great fights require truly substantial conflicts.
Shockingly, the violent release of smoke, fire, and meteoric debris is positioned more as a climactic afterthought than as the main attraction.
On one hand, the film is surely a celebration of a land's distinct creatures and the people who live among them, but on the other, it's a culture's biting auto-critique.
It's all provocatively kooky, and ample spoilers forbid ample explanation, but Trance also draws out Boyle's less dazzling commercial side, not to mention his penchant for whirling excess.
It winningly reflects how to utilize quiet understandings and, yes, very loud laughter.
Writer-director Paul Weitz's proudly boisterous star vehicle for Lily Tomlin has about as many ambitions as it does delusions.
Magic Mike XXL plays like the party bus whose road was charitably paved.
The film uses its male-on-male boundary-leaping to give the shopworn man-boy narrative a refresh.
Director Natalia Leite, with the aid of cinematographer Tobias Datum's handheld camera, dutifully follows her on her id-driven journey.
Jamie Dornan somehow manages to render his sculpted beauty moot, which throws a major wrench in the gears for a film dependent on eroticism.
A choppy, feature-length progression of crude, predictable gags, the film plays like a variety show, and yet its main attraction is barely funny enough to warrant his own brief sketch.
This PG-rated romp is, refreshingly, less notable for its happily-ever-afters than its oh-no-they-didn'ts.
It places regurgitated ideas into the mouths of gifted actors, then drops them amid a kooky story that plays like an elaborate distraction from what little the film actually has to say.
David Frankel crams his story with predictable developments, yet he matches his subject in spirit, pushing something into the spotlight that, however unlikely, elicits irresistible glee.
No matter how much Bertrand Bonello varies his split screens, triptychs, and geometric screen divisions, he forgets that one of the most fashionable virtues is knowing when to leave.
Of Bennett Miller's many directorial feats, his canniest is his depiction of the precariousness of bonds, and how those bonds can shift, drastically yet almost imperceptibly.
The film boldly raises the unanswerable question of whether it's better for an artist to safely isolate his work or tweak it a bit so as to share it with the world.
We may have all wanted to know the story behind those famed horns, but the mystery was far preferable to having Maleficent defanged and declawed in the process.
The film doesn't aim to condemn the fools who believe racism in America has ended, but rather open a vast discussion of how the subject of race--and merely identity--in our country has evolved.
The film's chief misstep is taking its title too literally, and ultimately depicting Louie as an indestructible, and thus largely inhuman, superhero.
The filmn is guilty of some of the same quick judgment it clearly doesn't endorse, exploiting Julian Assange's unmistakable appearance to help give itself a boogeyman.
The latest collaboration between director Jaume Collet-Serra and star Liam Neeson is made with far more care and visual detail than you might expect.
In the film, Alexander Payne's overview of America is extraordinarily, multifariously profound.
Viewer/character solidarity only holds up for so long, and the film falls hard into twisty, nonsense territory, skipping over its stronger themes in the process.
This may be the year's best superhero movie because, for a sufficient amount of time, it doesn't feel like a superhero movie at all.
As a film about social issues, and simply being yourself, it's commendably progressive, going so far as serving as a kind of coming-out story.

The movie, of course, barrels toward climax upon climax, and while possibly better photographed, the crashes, bangs, and booms are no less numbing than anything else you've seen in this summer of garbage blockbusters.
Roland Emmerich makes love of country into a thing of unabashed hokum, which bleeds through every nook of this overstuffed jumble and leaves no character untouched.
Sofia Coppola seems curiously unmotivated to bring full analysis or provocation to her themes, leaving the film feeling like a disappointingly toothless satire.
An angry indie that favors hollow ridicule over credibility.
A twisted, spirited exercise in stark juxtaposition, a grindhouse fairy tale of sorts that pairs the sugary sweet with the nastily violent.
It showcases the evolving interests and talents of Zal Batmanglij and Brit Marling, but expands them and channels them into a more traditional thriller framework.
Epic is a major aesthetic triumph for Blue Sky Studios.
Layered conflicts mount as this lean film treks on, and they're not limited to gender politics.
The second recent release that aims to channel great, time-honored storytelling without being able to tell a great story.
When The Great Gatsby actually stops to breathe, there is some greatness to be found, however brief it may be.
Not even when the doomed Juliet reaches for Romeo's dagger do you feel a single vicarious pain in your gut.
Matthew Miele has made a department store of a documentary, stocked to the hilt with an obscene inventory of storylines, talking heads, and utterly tasteless choices.
I'll tell you what's insane: the probability that folks will go easy on this dreck because it's aimed at younger viewers, who are being distressingly trained to expect little from their art.
The film feels second-rate in every sense, from the quality of its animation to its C-list voice cast.
Part end-of-life romance, part grossly manipulative mush, the film tries to stare grief and mortality in the face while practically shitting rainbows.

To really appreciate the film, one needs to look past James Franco's lack of formal poetry and focus on Scott Haze's performance and Cormac McCarthy's themes, which, given the great might of both, isn't exactly hard to do.
Steered by a lead actor and director, Joshua Michael Stern, who are both way out of their respective leagues, Jobs is excrutiating, failing to entertain and all but pissing on its subject's grave.
It works too hard to keep matters on an even, we're-all-more-alike-than-different keel, which is just one part of its chief problem of forcefully conveying information and intent.
Writer-director David E. Talbert adapts his own 2003 novel into something as useless as it is implosive.
Both keenly calculated and flowing with offbeat, naturalistic detail, Hanif Kureishi's jewel of a script reflects his sensibilities as a playwright.
The ultimately forgettable Runner Runner is, for a gambling film, markedly risk-averse.
The raison d'être of popping-and-locking scenes is trumped by tired team-building bathos, whose flagrancy is anything but conducive to spreading the film's hug-it-out bro-love.
Greedily tries to cram every dystopian curse into one misbegotten plot, resulting in something wildly disjointed, even if its pieces arguably connect.
You never learn why, exactly, she deserves a feature-length portrait. "Maybe people will get sick of me," Roitfeld muses. A little more than 90 minutes should do the trick.
Beautiful, poetic, and hard-hitting without the use of excessive force and deeply layered with evolving and regional nuances of feminine experience.
It doesn't play like reality, but like boilerplate filmic fantasy, and its novel setting and inception struggles seem positioned as a beard--or veil, if you will--to mask its mediocrity.
A work that's deadly serious and yet so goofily unbound that, in some scenes, incest truly seems like it's on the scandalous menu.
Some of the film's most memorable moments involve Niall and Liam looking down on oceans of screaming devotees in the street, and controlling their cheers like orchestra conductors.

Though always speeding forward in some gear of ridiculousness, the film is a lot more fun when it's completely nonsensical, before its baddie's motives and harebrained plot are funnel-fed to the viewer.
You're Next brazenly merges the home-invasion thriller with the dysfunctional family dramedy.
The movie﻿ blasts by for a while as an odd and busy slice of highly watchable garbage.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's tremendous dramatic value to the aching and sometimes devastating scenes that home in on these kids' private torments.
The near-imperceptible finesse of Abby's characterization reflects writer-director Stacie Passon's effortless, interesting mix of richness and economy.
Confused, poorly executed, sporadic and incredibly messy, but despite its pitfalls, My Soul to Take is an enormously entertaining bad movie.
Considering the naughty subject matter, Middle Men is a shockingly dull affair.
An exciting slice of action cinema, a poignant drama, a snarky southern-fried comedy and a knockout road picture.
At just 70 minutes, Firebreather plays more like a pilot for a TV series than a real film, but it has its moments.
A powerhouse performance piece for Jamie Foxx and a rock solid biopic.
Pretty heavy on cliches, but the simple fact that the film's one giant popcorn-infused action sequence should please most action fans.
Mostly well made, with solid performances, but there's very little that's fresh or original about this remake.
The film borrows from dozens of classic heist pictures, but adds very little fresh, original or exciting to the mix.
More like "Attack of the (Rob) Zombies." A knockout cast is wasted in a tired, dumb horror movie with more embarrassing moments than real thrills.
Occasionally preposterous and bogged down by Haggis' usual lack of subtlety, but the film is also captivating and energetic, particularly during the thrilling final act.
AvN is occasionally campy fun, but it's mostly just dull and and disappointing, never living up to the potential of its terrific title.
Hardly fresh or original, but S.W.A.T.: Firefight is an enjoyable, action-packed follow-up to the 2003 original and one of the better DTV titles out there.
Hardly a knockout, but Megamind is an immensely enjoyable animated adventure that spoofs and pays homage to the superhero genre.
Driven by James Franco's charisma and Danny Boyle's bizarrely antiquated, but refreshingly sharp sense of style, 127 Hours is as exciting as a film about a guy stuck to a rock could possibly be.
The story, while classic in nature, is a bit thin, but Bambi is a breathtaking, jaw-dropping showcase of the ingenuity and genius of Disney animators.
Four Lions doesn't always reach satirical perfection, but it comes fairly close.
Gruesome and incredibly exploitative. However, for better or for worse, I Spit on Your Grave shows us the raw, shocking reality of rape, in all its bloody viciousness.
movie_title: I Spit on Your Grave (Day of the Woman) (1978)

movie_review_blurb: With off-tempo editing, a jarring narrative and no likeable lead gluing the story together, the pieces of this film are no more enjoyable than staring at a puzzle that's yet to have been put together.
The Saw franchise ends with a blood-soaked whimper.
Raging Bull is a fascinating exploration of the mind of an emotionally disconnected man. It's brutal, crass and impossible to look away -- much like a real boxing match.
A bland, sloppy, paint-by-numbers slasher that crams a half-baked anti-technology theme down your throat.
A powerful, intoxicating spiritual drama with a swift, delicate emotional core and fascinating characters.
A solid crime drama, with shades of Michael Mann's Heat, but a sluggish pace and meandering middle drag things down a little.
Elements of the story drag on longer than expected, but the film is lifted up by its dynamic visuals, exciting set pieces and terrific voice cast.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A masterful, painstakingly crafted adventure about the nature of acceptance, and the tragedy of human nature.
Dated on many levels, but the film represents a fascinating slice of scientific history.
Just when you think the film is about to run out of steam, it picks up the pace and surprises you. It's not for everyone, to be sure, but it works in its own unusual way.
While the film might not work for fans of today's faster-paced horror/thrillers, The Broken is a creepy little pot boiler that's likely to get under the skin of many horror fans.
Borderland teeters between a torture film and a spiritual thriller, but it also plays around with both genres in very intriguing ways.
Unfortunately, The Graves is a tedious horror film and a complete waste of several talented actors (Bill Mosely, Clare Grant, Tony Todd, Amanda Wyss).
Enormously entertaining, thought-provoking and fascinating despite a flawed, possibly biased screenplay.
Still loaded with action and wonderful characters, but this is the least of the three pictures.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its age, El Mariachi holds up remarkably well. The film's low budget (roughly $7,000, allegedly) actually helps build tension in the narrative - like you're watching something that's really happening.
Not only is Case 39 deplorable and morally off-center, the film is dull to boot.
Occasionally quite funny, and oddly relevant to the nature of our culture, but this dinner is a little underwhelming.
Starts out strong but things get a little wonky toward the finale. Sadly, the film is far too married to the faux trailer footage.
The seams are obvious in this faux documentary, but the thrills are fairly genuine.
A fascinating if potentially flawed interpretation of C.S. Lewis' beloved Narnia series.
A thoroughly entertaining western revenge thriller.
A few moments of inspired comedic genius spread throughout a sophomoric, disturbingly irresponsible little comedy.
The animation is fine, and the kids are bound to enjoy it, but Open Season 3 boasts a dull story that feels like it's on autopilot.
An incredibly dull low-key thriller barely driven by its two A-list leads.
For a movie about hyper-intelligent human beings, Limitless is surprisingly sloppy and ultimately rather brainless.
The cast is great, but the material is dated, and the political thrills are not always perfectly sharp.
Conan the Barbarian isn't offensively bad, just mediocre and forgettable in nearly every way imaginable.
One of the best horror-thrillers of the classic era, and a massively inspirational piece of cinema.
A masterpiece of the modern film noir genre, a terrific performance piece for everyone involved and an absolutely outstanding directorial effort.
The film borrows from too many sources, and almost always comes up short, lacking depth, character or reason.
Dull and overlong at times, but also scary when it needs to be.
Simply put, Beverly Hills Cop is one of the best buddy cop movies ever made.
American Graffiti is a music-infused tone poem - a fond, delicate trip back to an era often forgotten.
An incredibly fascinating, star-making film that never fails to intrigue.
Super 8 works best when it isn't attempting to imitate '80s Spielberg.
A dazzlingly enjoyable, memorable road trip of comedy and music from two of SNL's best.
Take Me Home Tonight is a much deeper, dramatic movie than most give it credit for. And it's also a hoot, too - largely thanks to Dan Fogler and the amusing cameo appearances.
Tons of action and butt-kicking, but the story is on autopilot, performances are stilted, and the film's budget can't keep up with director Anderson's daunting scope and scale.
An incredibly moving, character-rich drama about life in South Central L.A.
Packed with in-jokes, great characters and an offbeat anti-hero, Rango is the perfect shake-up the animated genre needed.
Silly, dull, and poorly made, with not much versus action.
An energetically quirky social metaphor, political commentary and action/sci-fi farce all balled up into one outrageously enjoyable experience, provided you like the work of Terry Gilliam.
Insidious clearly borrows from several sources, but where it fails as a narrative, it succeeds as a shock-a-minute fright fest with plenty of atmosphere and dread.
13 Assassins evokes a classic filmmaking style sharpened by Takashi Miike's modern energy.
Easily one of the best teen sex comedies of all time and quite possibly the best frat comedy ever made.
A passable, but emotionally empty, action film that fails to capitalize on its interesting characters.
While the ultimate conclusion is still the same as always, and Ashton Kutcher's flat delivery nearly ruins it, No Strings Attached is a thoughtful twist on the usual romantic-comedy.
An intriguing marital dramedy that rides the line between great and awful, often undone by lazy editing.
Skyline might be a midnight B-movie, but it's also hopelessly inept and a grievous waste of time and talent with no ending whatsoever.
Runs through all the same cliches, but Husk has it's interesting twists and turns, and plenty of atmosphere.
Run-of-the-mill is nearly every way, at least Prowl is scary on occasion.
A triple dosage of medicore, southern-fried mayhem, comedy and car chases.
Dirty Mary Crazy Larry is a classic heist chase picture driven by a somewhat dated premise and paper-thin characters.
Hubble provides a vivid, breathtaking look at our solar system like never before. And it leaves us pondering not just science, but faith.
A haunting, visceral trip through the mind of a man on the edge of his own sanity.
Flawed, to be sure, but beautifully crafted, unimaginably complex, visually dazzling, rich with metaphor and deeply affecting.
A sharp, even amusing, homage to comic book lore, a great family-friendly action-comedy, and a thoughtful marital drama all wrapped up in a deliciously exciting package.
Far more emotionally complex and scary than any previous entry - Potter 7.1 is the franchise's best chapter yet.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A little uneven, highlighting an unlikable character, but also incredibly enjoyable when the film is focused on the magnificently imaginative Narnian visuals.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For a movie called Dinoshark, the narrative is surprisingly dull. But it makes up for it during the amusing action set pieces.
Hardcore "Planeteers" will probably have some nostalgia for this one, but Captain Planet is a pretty cheesy show.
movie_title: Captain Planet and the Planeteers - Hero for Earth (1990)

movie_review_blurb: Hardly award-worthy entertainment, and pretty visually dated, but probably one of the better video game movies ever made comparatively.
I'll give it this - Mortal Kombat: Annihilation is hilarious. Sadly, not intentionally so.
Chuck Norris Karate Kommandos is pretty terrible stuff, the result of a bad idea combined with even weaker animation. But expect to laugh yourself silly for a good two hours.
It's often ridiculous, and filled with '80s cheese, but Teen Wolf does harbor some poignant coming-of-age metaphors and decent helping of intentional, and unintentional, comedy.
Street Kings 2 treads common ground, but it does its best on a limited budget, providing some noteworthy thrills.
Certainly uneven at times, but Terry Gilliam's surreal mood piece paints a vivid, splashy picture of gonzo journalist Hunter S. Thompson.
movie_title: Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (1998)

movie_review_blurb: A near-perfect coming-of-age story peppered with regret, pain, nostalgia and love.
Devil is pretty obvious in its intentions, with not-so-subtle religious metaphors spread throughout, but the film delivers enough thrills and chills to keep audiences entertained.
Simply put, Jean-Pierre Jeunet was the absolute wrong choice for this film. His award-winning quirky French visual sensibilities don't mesh well with Joss Whedon's meat-and-potatoes script.
Guaranteed to keep the kids entertained, but the film shamelessly borrows from far too many other movies to keep the adults happy.
While fans of The Doors probably already know the story, this exploration of Jim Morrison's life and career is fascinating nonetheless.

Extraordinary Measures strives to tug at our heartstrings, and educate us on a little publicized disease, but it ends up feeling like a drug itself - manufactured using artificial chemicals by technicians in a cold lab.
A painful, unfunny, unoriginal, sloppy mess of a movie.
movie_title: The 41-Year-Old Virgin Who Knocked Up Sarah Marshall And Felt Superbad About It (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Save yourself the time and money, watch a softcore skin flick on Cinemax and forget this film exists.
An uncomfortable experience, to say the least. But also quite rewarding.
The Children is a surprisingly tense, slow-brewing horror film that plays on current trends (rabid flu-like infections) and refreshes old clichéd conventions (killer children).
Basically, [Donald P.] Borchers' adaptation of Children of the Corn is one-part nasty bickering, two-parts boring corn chase.
Manipulative and flawed, but interesting and occasionally moving.
A terrifically entertaining movie, and a sharp, funny social commentary from start to finish.
Defiance is heavy-handed, but emotionally compelling, engaging and inspiring throughout.
A terrific, but way too brief, examination of the franchise, but this would have made a much better special feature than a full fledged DVD release.
The film is simply too brief, too befuddled and too delirious to do the comic book legend justice.
Masterful suspense and horror from one of the greats.
Grindhouse is a great experience, packed with fun, thrills, chills and gore galore.

Night of the Demons is far from great. But considering the truly awful, unwatchable direct-to-video horror titles that make their way to retail and rental shelves, it's easily among the best of the bunch.
Predators lovingly embraces its B-movie roots, but drags along the cinematic trappings, too.
Amusing in spots but too sporadic and slow-going.
Back to the Future is one of the best popcorn movies ever made. It's ingenuity, time-traveling twist ups and wonderfully vibrant characters resonate in ways few films ever achieve.
Revolutionary Road offers nothing you can't see on TV, with more compelling narratives and better performances (save for Michael Shannon).
This vampire comedy will drain you dry.
An expensive, low-rent, overlong, tired romantic action-comedy.
Field of Screams will have its fans. It's certainly gory, crass, riddled with female nudity and off-the-wall antics. But the narrative never amounts to anything interesting.
It's a mixture of some very clever, but unguided ideas.
If you're one of the cautious fans wary of the remake, do yourself a favor -- drop your reservations and give The Karate Kid a look.
Quite sadly Get Him to the Greek just doesn't work in the way it was meant to. Despite an ambitious metaphor, the film is far too mean-spirited to tickle our funny-bone.
A trippy, complex, thrill-driven action-adventure that demands (and rewards) repeat viewings.
Dark Days is hardly mediocre, but barely interesting; lacking a solid hook like the first film.
Certainly gory and goofy at times, but nearly as amusing as the first, riddled with unlikable characters, lazy dialogue and a dull middle act.
The film might not host an original concept, but its attention to detail - the tiny things that made '80s slashers unique - render Hatchet a far more enjoyable experience than its competition.
The single greatest sci-fi camp fest ever put on celluloid. This film boasts the perfect blend of goofy cheese and unhinged imagination.

The Human Centipede won't be everyone's cup of tea, but if you're willing to sit through the film's gory moments, and delve deeper into the narrative, there's something genuinely enthralling about this shocker.
Inception is certain to leave audiences wanting, but in the best way imaginable.
Despite the meandering pace, and lack of fearsome thrills, After.Life is a chilling fairytale that grabs you and takes you on a strangely hypnotic ride.
Crumb may be rough around the edges, even occasionally tedious, but what Zwigoff manages to uncover is honest, captivating and strangely visceral.
An enjoyably inventive low-budget B-movie filled with action and interesting characters.

Operation: Endgame is a film more about the journey than the destination. Forget that the film has a real plot and focus in on the brutally hilarious one-liners, snarky sarcasm and biting cynicism the film oozes in the first half.
A classic story of redemption, love, purity and friendship - a film worthy of our love and attention.
The Hangover might not be top class indie pop art, but the film represents the best of what comedy can provide -- pure, unadulterated, slaphappy entertainment. And there's nothing wrong with that.
An unforgettable horror film that doesn't just get under my skin - it stays there.
It's easily the best film I've ever seen about an evil woman-raping sea monster.
For true Ray Harryhausen fans, Jason and the Argonauts will remain one of his greatest feats. And if you bring yourself back to the era, you'll find a world of wonder yourself.

Sure, [Back to the Future II] has a clunky first act - which takes place in a hilariously overblown futuristic society - but the film knows just how, and when, to entertain us, and it does so in spades.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Absurd and quirky at times, The Matador plays like a "Bizarro World" variation of a James Bond film. It's beautifully shot, strange and deeply meaningful.
Back to the Future Part III continues to move the spirit of the series forward in new and exciting directions, and it reaches a satisfying conclusion to the overarching story.
movie_title: Back to the Future Part III (1990)

movie_review_blurb: A lousy horror film that retreads every scare from the first film with significantly less effectiveness.
Ultimately, Superman/Shazam! is a satisfying short, but it barely scrapes the surface of this character's potential, which is just a shame.
movie_title: Superman/Shazam! The Return of Black Adam (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Big Bad Mama strikes the perfect balance between exploitative raunchiness, and great low-key action and excitement.
The film wonderfully tears down the conventions of '50s womanhood, while providing loads of quirky fun along the way.
Spiritually moving, visually daring and emotionally stirring, Avatar is classic storytelling at its very best.
Certainly not a great film, but an enjoyable slice of surprisingly low-key, classic '80s action filmmaking complete with an awesome cast.
The film is an unmitigated disaster, a putrid patchwork of the original series stitched together by wretched performances, bad creative decisions and a story that's all exposition, no depth.
An ugly and disturbing deconstruction of self-destruction and emptiness.
Light on logic, and not always polished, the film plays like a gonzo big-budget Roger Corman B-movie. It's filled with wonderfully imaginative visuals, interesting characters and spectacle galore.
The third act's a little clumsy, but Elf brings the Christmas cheer and loads of laughs.
This action-comedy has its moments, but its flaws often outweigh the action spectacle and story.
A beautifully creepy, hypnotic horror-thriller that paints a vivid picture of why del Toro is such a beloved, wonderfully haunting filmmaker today.
A moody, tense, moving and action-packed crime drama -- one of Woo's very best.
The A-Team is a can of soda -- empty calories, full of fizz. But like a good, cold can of soda on a hot summer day, it's curiously refreshing, tasty and it hits the spot.
A lightweight, but highly enjoyable buddy cop movie elevated by its two lead stars.
There are quite a few fun and hilarious moments to be had thanks to a knockout supporting cast, but there's a reason we've never followed "the other guys" before.
Despite its sloppy, often outlandish, story, and obvious twists, the film does work, if only as an enjoyably intense, and surprisingly bleak, B-movie that rarely lets up once it gets going.
Girls get tortured in a foreign country. It's competently made, but we've seen it all before.
Certainly not awful, but the producer's dedication to Stephenie Meyer's drawn-out story creates a lumbering third movie that borderlines on downright dull.
A symphony of sound, animation and unbridled Disney spirit.
Creepy animation and a somewhat tired retelling might have you longing for the Muppet adaptation instead. At least the film's 3D-designed visuals are breathtaking.

It goes without saying, these final two chapters of the "Harry Potter" legacy are more than a little monumental. And director David Yates does not falter in delivering a rousing, epic fantasy/adventure worthy of the term "classic."
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's almost no plot, and loads of schmaltz, but the hidden metaphors and cast chemistry makes this a worthwhile effort.

The film doesn't tread any new ground, at least in terms of the narrative, but the breathtaking visuals, heartwarming themes, spirited action and energetic voice cast make this one animated title audiences of all ages should check out.
Despite some truly fantastic work throughout the '90s and 2000s, Se7en still remains director David Fincher's best film, albeit by a very narrow margin.
A great midnight movie experience in the theaters, but the film itself is a bit of a bore.

Ridley Scott's Alien is nothing short of a masterpiece. Technically brilliant, tense, horrifying and visually breathtaking, there's not a moment in this B-monster movie that doesn't excel well beyond the usual genre trappings.
James Cameron's Aliens is easily one of the best sequels ever made, taking the original story and expanding upon it in ways most sequels are afraid to do.
It's a shame that Alien 3 nearly ruined the [Alien] franchise, but that doesn't make it a bad movie, just a bad sequel.
Perhaps a bit clumsy in the lumbering middle act, but Mad Max delivers the goods when it comes to pulse-pounding car chases and stunts.
A Nightmare on Elm Street wants to be fresh and original, but it's bound by the constricted confines of the original's classic moments.
Deeply flawed, but hilariously layered with stock footage, gobs of camp and a bizarre narrative.
Potter's third year is his most inventive yet.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: For some, The Goonies is a classic, but for others the film is simply a mediocre kids' flick.
Feels more like a brainstorm exercise than a feature length film.
A bit clumsy in spots, but Highlander is a thoroughly entertaining action-fantasy picture.
These toys may be old, but there's still plenty of mileage left in 'em.
The story is engrossing, but Mike Newell's adaption is a little too dull and by-the-numbers following Alfonso Cuaron's visual tour-de-force.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Once the monster is set loose, The Terror Within falls to pieces.
Unfortunately, this remake of Forbidden World isn't nearly as trippy and entertaining as the original, playing to the genre's conceptual cliches a bit too often.
Visually daring, ingenuous and extremely entertaining, Scott Pilgrim is virtually flawless.
"Toy Story 3" might not be the best film of the three, but it's still a classic compared to most animated fodder out there
A brilliant marketing campaign, to be sure, but this Z-grade con of a film offers no payoff for audiences looking to be scared.
TrollHunter is both creepy and funny, a clever combination for this sly monster movie.
The Cabin in the Woods is nothing short of brilliant.
The Fox and the Hound is a flawed, but effective kids' flick.
A slick, fast-paced greaser picture that shows off the incredible talent of director Robert Rodriguez.
The Innkeepers is an eerie, haunting and sometimes funny ghostly chiller that's bound to win over those with a taste for classic nail-biting horror.
11-11-11 has a few scary moments here and there, but it's mostly a flat, lifeless spiritual horror spin on The Number 23.
A sloppy, ugly, illogical story mixed with graphic torture, attempted rape and grisly violence. Mother's Day is a film only a mother could love.
The Grey is a powerful drama, a chilling tale of horror, and an uplifting, emotionally raw look at the nature of man and spiritually.
Haywire is a tired spy thriller that meshes the three styles of Steven Soderbergh - pop, clinical and indie - into one messy, sometimes dull B-movie.
Not nearly as endearing, nor as funny, as Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job, Billion Dollar Movie is likely to become a cult hit, but nothing more.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Gremlins hosts the perfect blend of Capraesque Christmas spirit, humorously tainted by stinging horror and hilarious offbeat comedy.
Wahlberg delivers in this sometimes tense, enjoyable, but morally muddy heist thriller.
An odd, but rewarding sequel that ups the ante on comedy and effects, and manages to offer a refreshing spoof of the first film.
Coriolanus plays a bit flat at times, but it's a challenging, and even exciting, piece of cinema that's sure to inspire much love from Shakespeare enthusiasts.
Certainly enjoyable and occasionally tense despite some wobbly performances and plot holes.
Safe House is fairly predictable at times, but it also boasts brutally intense, edge-of-your seat action and great star performances from Reynolds and Washington.
Goon is a remarkably sweet, shockingly violent and incredibly enjoyable movie that ranks up there as one of the best hockey films ever made.
Underworld: Awakening boasts some fun stylized action, and Kate Beckinsale back in that skin-tight outfit, but it also continues the franchise's streak of frustrating mediocrity.
John Carter is a visual delight at times, but the classic story is tiresome and the characters are largely unmemorable, leaving a cold, only occasionally thrilling experience.
While few newcomers will likely attach to Dragon Age: Dawn of the Seeker, the film provides a real treat for longtime fans of this franchise.
movie_title: Dragon Age: Dawn of the Seeker (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A bit slow and meandering, and unfunny when Bill Murray is not on screen, but Meatballs is worth it for the camp atmosphere and Murray's comic genius.
Visually rich with lavish sets and fun movie monsters, but Journey 2 is about as underdeveloped and hollow as assembly-line filmmaking can get.
Ghost Rider only excels when it embraces the gonzo direction of directors Neveldine and Taylor. Sadly though, the film seems to be pumping its brakes more than riding with a vengeance.
An energetic return to form reminding audiences, both young and old, why everyone should love The Muppets.
A very moody, well made retelling of Stieg Larsson's book, but the film also lacks much purpose and sometimes focuses on the grim with an exploitative eye.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Dream House is not the film it was advertised as, but beyond the wonky finale, reshoots, and strange editing there is an interesting tale to be told here.
Starts out great, almost like a pseudo sequel to Niccol's other sci-fi drama Gattaca, but slowly unravels into a mindless chase picture that never really captures any real depth or meaning.
Mocks torture porn while being the worst form of it all at the same time, The Human Centipede II personifies what not to do with a sequel.
Tower Heist succeeds because of Eddie Murphy's snarky performance, and fun turns from the rest of the cast. But the heist itself is a little dumb and the story is riddled with plot holes.
DiCaprio keeps the film afloat, but J. Edgar lacks any real controversy and never fully reaches deep within the man's dark psyche.
Puss in Boots delivers just the right mixture of fun, exciting and super cute.
One of the year's very best, Hugo is a rousing, moving, poignant tale being told on many more levels than what is seen on screen.
An immensely enjoyable thrill ride, but also an occasionally frustrating and short adaptation.
A knockout, tense action picture that proves there's plenty more life left in the Mission: Impossible franchise.
Weakly plotted and emotionally flat, but visually alluring, memorable and sometimes very entertaining.
The film might be too chaotic for some audiences, but for those willing to sit back and enjoy the rapid-fire ride, Happy Feet Two will bring a smile to your face.
Story and characters leave much to be desired, but there's something wonderful about this refreshingly gritty, innovative animated feature.
Battle Royale is a masterpiece of mayhem, violence and unfettered teen melodrama.
A crass, but sweet nod to Uncle Buck, flavored with funny characters, a few sparks of drama, and a few too many cliches.
Outstanding performances and fascinating visual design are somewhat marred by a slow pace and a dry narrative.
Hop starts out cute, but slowly dissolves into a mundane, droll experience completely derivative of Alvin and the Chipmunks and numerous Christmas movies.
An awfully made, awfully acted, awfully plotted, and awfully boring more. In a word, Creature is awful.
A well-made remake that adds quite a bit to the original story. Alas, The Ring also feels dated and dull.
A very entertaining, energetic film, highlighted by gravity-defying action set pieces. However, Tintin is also a bit emotionless, lacking character development.
A Necessary Death presents a wholly original, fascinating and curiously terrifying documentary that's likely to either captivate or revolt audiences.
The mystery and fun of the first feature is replaced with a bland miscast villain and slam-bang action nonsense, none of which is very impressive.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The parts are often funnier, and more memorable, than the whole, but there's enough here to keep David Wain fans smiling.
Appallingly cheap on every conceivable level, Jersey Shore Shark Attack is like watching a bad porno without the satisfaction of seeing any actual sex.
An absolutely awful sequel that flushes any potential this franchise might have otherwise had.
Editing is wonky, and the story leaves much to be desired, but Jason Statham genuinely shines in this rugged, violent action-thriller, with a body count that rivals classic John Woo.

The Victim is a labor of love, and despite the thin narrative and low-budget shortcomings, the film makes for an interesting midnight movie. It's a bit light on humor, sans the film's amusing finale, but there's just enough here to keep genre fans smiling.
The Star Wars of a new generation.
High School definitely won't be everyone's flavor of pot comedy, but it's certainly a fun trip and a clever spin on the genre.
A bit slow-going and strangely emotionless at times. But Bill Paxton's nervous expressions add humor, and the film's jaw-dropping glimpse at the Titanic are powerful, to say the least.
A staggering film, layered with melodramatic romance, tragedy, intensity and breathtaking production design.
Snow White boasts some clever visuals and engaging action, but the story feels forced and better fit for a SyFy movie of the week.
Halloween III: Season of the Witch might have been hated back in the day, but it simply doesn't deserve the anger and animosity nowadays.
movie_title: Halloween III - Season of the Witch (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Starship Troopers: Invasion is quite reminiscent of a video game cut scene, sans the joy of any actual gameplay.
Werewolf: The Beast Among Us is hardly the disaster many feared, but its not very good, either.
The Revenant is a refreshing spin on the vampire/zombie genre and a true hidden gem.
The Tall Man is a fine thriller that tragically falls off the rails, spiraling into dark, morally corrupt territory.
Resident Evil: Damnation is the best Resident Evil film to-date.
Dark Shadows should have been a return-to-form for director Tim Burton, but with a bloated budget and way too much room to play, Burton delivers yet another wasted effort.
A seriously entertaining, original, visual mind warp.
movie_title: The Haunted World of El Superbeasto (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly not perfect, but Bambi II isn't a bad DTV midquel.
Halloween II isn't a knockout sequel, but it's a solid, if slightly slow, follow-up to the original horror classic.
A bit overlong, with a surprisingly moody middle act, but writer/actor Jason Segel and director/co-writer Nicholas Stoller continue to perfectly balance the laughs with the drama.
Direction is sharp, but the dull assembly line story damages this hokey action picture that's occasionally so bad it's good.
Freelancers is a dull, lifeless cop drama built on cliches, powered by throwaway supporting performances from Forest Whitaker and Robert De Niro.
An enjoyable, if very sloppy, jaunt into total anarchy, Project X isn't a film about morals, but what happens when all rules are thrown out the window.
The FP is a mostly serious, straight-faced spoof of misogynistic gangland B-movies and sports dramas, and rarely does it fail to deliver sparks of originality and sly comedy.
Slick and funny as hell, 21 Jump Street is one of the best comedies of the year.
Certainly sloppy, but visually rich, exciting and, thanks to several great supporting roles, a better, more character-driven tale that tops the original despite a more intimate feel.
The Artist is superfluous, but charming through-and-through, painted with lively performances, staggering cinematography and a lovely spirit of nostalgia.
God Bless America is an angry film, with some good points and plenty of amusing satire, but it's ultimately bogged down by dull pacing and way too many rants and monologues.
American Reunion is one last slice of pie worth having. It's a tasty treat to the many fans who made this franchise what it is.
Lockout is a film derivative of several notable genre classics, but the film does offer some entertainment value.
Intruders is a slow-going psychological thriller with very few thrills and little intrigue.
Interesting one-take cinematography and a great performance by Elizabeth Olsen are very nearly ruined by a muddled story that leaves little room for replay value.
A wickedly violent, action-packed old school piece of warped, twist-filled sci-fi and Schwarzenegger cheese. You'll wish you had three hands to hold this one.
Watch the opening sequence, skip everything that else that follows.
Pretty much one long sketch painfully stretched to feature length - Casa de mi Padre would have been better served as a short film series on Ferrell's Funny or Die website.
A mostly harmless, cute and cuddly pop-infused babysitter for the ADD generation, but a wretched adaptation of Seuss' classic work.
Detention is a hypnotic hipster acid trip - a brazenly irreverent jolt to the system that screams cult gem.
An impressive production to say the least, Hatfields & McCoys is as exciting as it is lavish and beautiful.
The Raid: Redemption boasts an outstanding showcase of martial arts and stuntwork. The story might be thin, and the fighting a little repetitive, but The Raid is a knockout low-budget actioner.
The Hunger Games may be a flawed beast, to be sure, but there's plenty of subtext to glean from the narrative, and a slew of wonderfully rich characters worth investing in.
A few laughs here and there at the expense of offensive stereotypes, The Dictator mostly repeats jokes we've seen in other, better Sacha Baron Cohen films.
Funny in spots, but the story and characters have almost nowhere to go. The direction feels aimless and crafted like a DTV film. In other words, this is an enormously disappointing threequel.
A somewhat dry, but very good Disney animated effort punctuated by a few Disney-defining classic moments.
A terribly written, dubious slice of unscary found footage spiritual horror that ends with an ellipsis, not a period.
There's nothing really new about this remake/prequel, but the film's attention to continuity and detail is respectable and interesting for fans of John Carpenter's 1982 classic.
Lon Chaney delivers an awesome performance in this fine adaptation of the original Gaston Leroux novel.
Beautifully shot and always fascinating, Rare Exports succeeds on many levels. But the final payoff just never seems to come.
An eerie, atmospheric pre-code horror tale, adapted from H.G. Wells classic book, The Island of Dr. Moreau.
The film transcends the common barriers and becomes a living spiritual entity, encompassing the essence and tone of an era.
A slam-bang good time, Captain America: The First Avenger is one of Marvel's better efforts.
There's a lot more going on than meets the eye in this slick, exciting, UK monster movie.

Jurassic Park remains an incredible experience - one that never ceases to be entertaining. It's not an entirely faithful adaptation of Michael Crichton's popular novel, but the creative liberties it takes prove enormously ingenious.
A polarizing, but classic piece of children's entertainment filled with whimsy, horror, comedy and imagination.
movie_title: Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory (1971)

movie_review_blurb: While the plot has some minor flaws, the incredible performances, characters, soundtrack and action beats of Hanna more than make up for it.
The Crow is a visually immersive, emotionally wrought comic adaptation and one of the best gothic tales ever made.
Captain Jack Sparrow is running on fumes in this enjoyable, but middling, forgettable sequel.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A flat, talky, derivative "horror" film that's not very controversial despite how much it thinks it is.
A stale adaptation of the classic Frank Miller comic. The film drowns in bad voice work and lacks the visual nuances found in the original story.
There's a bit more character in the extended cut, but the film is still a mess of tones, driven by a Star Wars-like narrative but cut down by a sloppy Transformers feel.
A visually dazzling, intentionally polarizing examination of life and death, and the beauty and darkness hidden between.
Flawed, and not nearly as dark as it could be, but Horrible Bosses excels if only because of the fun performances and great chemistry of the cast.
Like the other sequels, The Howling Reborn takes a great concept and completely flushes it down the toilet in order to exploit modern horror/werewolf trends.
A much moodier, slower pace from Tarantino's other work, but Jackie Brown is one enjoyable flick that rewards its audience with each viewing.
Bad Teacher doesn't quite get an F. But an acceptable C+ is pretty fair.
One of the best gangster dramas ever made, driven by Pacino's haunting performance and De Palma's lightning pace.
One of the best films out there, and certainly a high point in early cinema. The love for Citizen Kane is deserved.
Bridesmaids is a very funny movie, with interesting characters and great performances, but the film's pacing issues make it more of a chore to get through than expected.
Surprisingly smart and filled with homage, Paul is crass and a little rough around the edges, but thoroughly enjoyable.
Super can be very affecting and emotionally disturbing, which might not suit everyone's tastes, but it's also an absorbing, bleak and sometimes funny deviation from the usual superhero fodder.
One of the funniest, coolest, most absurd cult films ever made, and one of the best from the dynamic duo - Joel and Ethan Coen.
The Ward should send some chills down your spine, but it probably won't stay with you.
Fast Times is a brilliant, funny and often challenging examination of teenage life in the early 1980s.
A surprisingly boring throwback to '80s fantasy, with a disgusting amount of potty humor, violence and foul language tossed in to generate the shallowest of laughs.
A pointless, very loose adaptation of the popular Italian comic that plays like a bad episode of Buffy.
Terrific action spectacle and a great tattered and beaten performance from Paul Giamatti, but the film is largely lifeless and dull.
The visual effects don't really hold up 10 years later, but Spy Kids is still a charming, energetic, inventive kids' flick that balances its goofier side with its a sense of dramatic maturity.
Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams is certainly trippy and inventive, but the film is way too long, a little too flat and not nearly as enjoyable as the original.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Spy Kids 3 is much sharper and funnier than the second outing, but the missing pieces, namely the parents and sister, are sorely needed.
Conan the Destroyer is a rather silly follow-up, with less raw emotion, less excitement and far too many dumb sidekicks.
A classic tale of revenge, love and madness is given a refreshing polish and shine by director Nicolas Winding Refn. Drive is one of the year's very best.
Takes a few views to really appreciate, but Peter Jackson's blood-splattered horror masterpiece is a gory good time.
While a visual treat, Mimic is exactly that, a film which mimics other styles and plot elements. In this case Alien and David Cronenberg's The Fly and Videodrome.
A masterpiece of epic filmmaking, a profound religious experience and one of the greatest films ever made.
A surprisingly powerful, and incredibly funny, little movie led by two terrific performances and John Hughes' razor sharp script.
The Naked Gun is still very funny more than 20 years later. Leslie Nielsen is awesome, and the gags are more hit than miss.
movie_title: The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad! (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Charmingly dated, but still immeasurably funny.
If you only watch Scream 4 once, it might prove satisfying. But the film fails to hold any value beyond its first screening, largely thanks to a sloppy script that feels like a rough draft.
A classic story told through immersive visuals, great voice work and some of the most memorable songs in movie history. The Lion King defines animated classic.
A classic tale is told through fascinating visuals, cheesy characters and good old fashioned muscle-bound strength.
Atlas Shrugged is a passionless experience that feels like a TV movie/miniseries. It's flat, poorly plotted, thinly performed and dull to its core
Redline doesn't boast much of a high-art story or clever dialogue, but the animation, stylistics and tone are art and visual stimuli at their very best.
A fascinating look at how we're winning and losing the "war" on drugs.
By no means is Real Steel an original film, at least in terms of its base story, but that doesn't mean it's not an effective, tear-jerking kids movie.
Delves far more into the mythology of the series, which may render the picture less scary to some, but there's still enough thrills and chills to keep most audiences thoroughly freaked.
Scary at times, but uninspired and often illogical.
Offbeat, dark and quirky, with plenty of atmosphere. But the film strays into dull territory all too often.
Poorly made on nearly every conceivable level, Cross is a genre-meshed mess.
Predictable and a bit sloppy on many levels, but occasionally effective, scary and somewhat intriguing.
movie_title: Cyrus: Mind Of A Serial Killer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Awful on nearly every level, but wholly entertaining as a laugh-out-loud party movie. Shark Night is dumb, but you probably won't care.
Not as fresh or frightfully exciting as the first film, but certainly scary, occasionally inventive and almost always enjoyable.
The film is pretty thin, but the scares are effective and creepy.
Certainly inspirational and occasionally haunting, with great effects, Don't Be Afraid of the Dark is also a bit overlong and padded.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid of the Dark (1973)

movie_review_blurb: While the show is dated in many respects, the plot, characters and narrative twists are still a delight. And the series' ambitious action, production design and effects are noteworthy achievements.
movie_title: Captain Power and the Soldiers of the Future - V. 5 - A Fire in the Dark (1988)

movie_review_blurb: An outstanding look at the enormously dysfunctional relationship between a creator and his adoring fans.
A misfire to be sure, Burke & Hare's comedic timing feels one step off, resulting in a film with solid performances and an amusing story, but not many laughs and not much replay value.
Rough around the edges, but The Wild Hunt is thoroughly entertaining, engaging and even a bit tense.
Not quite as disturbing as the first two films, or as metaphorically fascinating, but full of clever twists and turns. Hostel Part III is a better-than-average low-budget thriller.
A masterpiece of B-movie horror-comedy mayhem fueled by Sam Raimi's fast-paced slapstick sensibilities and brought to life by Bruce Campbell's incredible performance.
Slow moving, with cheesy visual effects and some nasty B-movie trappings. But the story and setting are both dreary and fascinating. And performances are top notch.
Even subtracting Taylor Lautner's mechanical performance, Abduction is an illogical train wreck riddled with messy direction, bad editing, tired action and plot holes galore.
Remarkable action set pieces and stunning effects, but this third outing of Transformers is sometimes just as clunky and irritating as the second.
Stale and bland, Killer Elite is an emotionless, assembly-line actioner with little to keep even the hardest of hardcore fans interested.
A wonderfully rich adaptation of the final book's last act, but the central focus on the three leads might leave some fans disappointed, especially those seeking a more thorough adaptation.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A foul misfire that favors sex and gross-out gags over its somewhat affecting plot about married life and single life, and the sacrifices we all make for one or the other.
Cars 2 is a very messy concoction, but it does prove entertaining every once in a while.
A complete waste of time and talent, The Scorpion King 3 is a cheap, poorly made cash-grab with little action, little story and nothing interesting to offer.
movie_title: The Scorpion King 3: Battle For Redemption (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The kids might enjoy it, but The Smurfs is nothing but an annoying, noisy commercial for Sony products. Save for Hank Azaria's amusing take on Gargamel, the film is fatty junk food.
The science of this science fiction tale is about as wobbly as the rest of the picture. It's the dramatic punches and solid performances from the leads that keep this one afloat.
A mercilessly boring, wasted opportunity that forgets to have a sense of humor, charisma, or aliens.
Visually dazzling, well shot and perhaps richer in character than the first film -- but also nowhere near as clever, refreshing or funny.
A charming adventure tale, in the spirit of 1930's serials, The Rocketeer is a fun ride.
Fright Night has some rough patches, but the film is entertaining through-and-through, largely thanks to Colin Farrell's predatory performance.
30 Minutes or Less lacks logic, and it doesn't make use of its title concept in any interesting way, but the film is funny, fast and entertaining through-and-through.
There's nothing profound or mysterious about Straw Dogs. The performances are solid, but the movie is mostly forgettable.
A bit emotionless and clinical, but Contagion is a pretty spot-on blow-by-blow of what it would be like if a real viral epidemic were to break out.
Warrior is an unbelievably effective film, not just because it's emotionally rich, but because it doesn't treat the MMA sport like a joke.
The best animated film of the year, Kung Fu Panda 2 plays as a solid kids' film, a great kung fu actioner, and an emotionally centered drama.
The action set pieces are elaborately staged and sometimes exciting, but the dull script, overcooked direction and wonky editing damage this otherwise enjoyable B-movie.
The deaths are just as gruesome and fun as ever, but the script's utter lack of originality drags things down quite a bit.
Apollo 18 is a mercilessly dull movie that just doesn't make much sense. It's light on thrills, and the found-footage gimmick works against the tension.
Don't Be Afraid of the Dark might not play as well for adults, but younger audiences (namely preteens) will likely enjoy the hell out of this one.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film is especially valuable to people with limited knowledge of a major orchestra because it breaks the culture apart and gives its many voices individuality and intimacy.
It captures the heart and spirit of one of the 20th century's most fabled ballet companies, with a history that stretches continents and decades.
Anyone who knows about ballet will find much to recognize in the lives of these young women, but for those who do not, the film will be a revelation.
Filmed with affection, taste, warmth and, yes, truth.
Even if you don't enjoy Red Sparrow in the same way the filmmakers intended, it's a solid spy movie if you want an excuse to turn off your brain for two hours and 20 minutes.
Woody Allen doesn't have much left to say. Wonder Wheel is a doddering rehash of ideas from his earlier works.
... in the hands of writer/director Martin McDonagh, what emerges is a seriously dark and thoughtful comedy.
With a twisty storyline that borrows from multiple genres, it's sort of like a one-man band. It may sound muddled, but it's unique enough that it's hard to look away.
Director Vivek Agnihotri's sophomore effort is a heavy-handed, cliché-ridden mess, which is worsened by the corny and uneven paint-by-numbers script.
The film lacks creativity in the second half, failing to bring its reincarnation tale to a satisfactory conclusion.
Step Up 2 the Streets is the latest of this genre more obsessed with dancing than with a good story, which, despite all the explosive dance routines, results in an unsatisfying experience.

Bollywood's attempts at making socially relevant films usually end up preachy, but superstar-actor-turned-first-time-director Khan hits the bull's-eye with this minimalist story of a boy struggling with dyslexia.
There's great chemistry between superstars Roshan and Rai Bachchan. Their solid performances bring home Jodhaa Akbar's saga of star-crossed lovers.
Yet another lazy farce from hack director Anees Bazmee that leaves a sour taste in your mouth despite loads of charm and coolness from Khan.

[The film] borrows the plot structure from classic Bollywood love triangles. But director Mandeep Kumar brings a breezy quality to the narrative, keeping the action moving to create a funny, entertaining film that has fresh characters and sharp dialogue.
This Bollywood puffery is an ill-conceived mess that has absolutely no direction.
Gender equality gets an entertaining treatment in the ensemble drama Ik Kudi Punjab Di.
Despite the superstars, the high production values, and abundant gloss from leading Indian studio Yash Raj Films, the film fails.
Ultimately, the film goes off-track and into the realm of serious melodrama, and loses the audience.
Sarkar delivers a long monologue at the end of the film that explains what really happened: chiefly that the power plant was just a ruse for a power struggle. Too bad Varma didn't make that film.
The problem is that although the political backdrop is somewhat intriguing, the film's forced and muddling song, dance, and romance is lacking the entertainment quotient big-time.
Bollywood veteran Kher is in top form, and so is Randhawa, proving that she was no fluke in the hit Punjabi film Tera Mera Ki Rishta.
While the filmmakers try to crank up the fun factor full blast for another zany adventure centered around the Golmaal crew, the laughs seem forced and somewhat tiresome.
With the exception of some well-orchestrated physical comedy in the vein of Charlie Chaplin, Housefull is excruciatingly painful to sit through.

A concoction of disjointed scenes dressed up as eye candy in the form of pretty boys and beauties in an absurd story that wouldn't even hold up in a fantasy world, let alone the real world it supposedly portrays.

movie_review_blurb: "Mammuth" has the distressed, gritty look of a 1970s movie. (It was shot on Super 16 reversal film.) But it takes its cues from some of the less-appealing aspects of that era's freewheeling style, in particular a sort of curdled whimsy.
"Shaolin" fits in the more somber kung-fu tradition. But it also finds room for the genre's comic strain.
Shows, perceptively and often sweetly, a broader slice of young, urban, educated life in India as the three deal with careers, love and happiness.
"Flypaper" has enough twists and surprises to remain interesting in a closed-room, Agatha Christie kind of way. But it's never quite as clever or as hip as it thinks it is.
Subtle it ain't and subtle it needn't be. It is, though, mostly involving (if Bollywood long, at 2 hours 45 minutes) and even occasionally stirring.
Ultimately, the first impression given - of a place both familiar and strange - is the only impression offered. It's not enough.
The movie bucks Hollywood norms without quite knowing what to put in their place.

More and more, Bollywood movies are urban tales for urban audiences. What feels most backward-glancing about "Singham" is its uncomplicated, even cartoonish insistence on the benefits of village soil over city dirt for cultivating bedrock Indian values.
[It] is undone by its very premise: that the two stories it tells can coexist in the same film.

It's cute, sort of, as well as crudely slapstick and sweetly picaresque, and just a bit misty and crispy.

A running joke is that Mr. Harvey has thrown men under the bus by giving away their secrets. But, gents, if they were secrets they wouldn't be clichés.
Don's crisis of faith, which should be the movie's core and engine, is never really convincing. It's spelled out but dramatically inert, lost among the yuks of the Reed kookiness.

When a small drama sputters to life at the end, it's too late. You've already been lulled into dreamland.

Passionate, contentious, funny, sincere, politically attuned.

The movie goes mushy when it should be critical, and leaves you with questions that it's not prepared to answer.

Mr. Kumar and Katrina Kaif mug and dance and work hard, but they're not called upon to play characters so much as shtick figures, and the cartoonish world they inhabit isn't appealing or buoyant enough to carry the day.

It's not just that Mr. Shadyac makes big leaps and sometimes papers over contradictions. It's also that after a while everyone starts to sound the same: a little beatific, a little high on wonder, a little platitudinous.
The movie too often fails to reward the close watching it requires. While its stillness powerfully suggests stasis, its fragmentary approach doesn't achieve a cumulative power.
Ms. Rao does have an ace up her sleeve, though: Prateik, who in his first lead role gives a nuanced, career-making performance.

movie_review_blurb: A pleasant enough time-pass, as they say in India, but stays too near the surface to be memorable.

These are vivid, flawed, even introspective characters. And they're classic American strivers. With rodeo, but not just that, they hope to go beyond where they have been.

Looks at dying in a comic-cosmic way that embraces both magical thinking and fatalism.

The film, much of it set in a rebel camp in Andhra Pradesh, seems torn between two storytelling modes: episodic with a documentary flavor and action-driven pulp. It makes a hash of both.
Artful but not arty, Mr. Ratnam, whose films include Dil Se and Guru, delivers the goods.
The film -- full of romance, intrigue and fraternal strife -- is too diffuse to score political points. Or to have much impact.

Though clearly a labor of love by Mr. Bhattacharya, "Tagore" is mostly clumsy as filmmaking.
A star can lift a movie like "Kick," making its silliness sublime. That doesn't happen here.
The director, Sajid Khan, who wrote the script with Robin Bhatt and Akarsh Khurana, seems insulated and unable to tease out the difference between inspiration and indulgence.
Mr. Hirani remains an excellent storyteller, weaving his disparate story strands into a convincing, satisfying whole - a rare Bollywood feat.

While Ms. Collette grounds Ellie and her emotions in a tough-minded plausibility, she can only hint at what the script fails to deliver: the complexities of a flawed woman's midlife crisis.
An inviting sense of mystery hangs over the events of 1947, Ms. Kurys's origin story. There are some things, she seems to say, that we never fully understand, including the people we are closest to.
"2 States" is an effort to go beyond formula while also embracing formulaic elements, including some nice song-and-dance sequences. The mix isn't right yet.
It holds your interest, even if Jean-Marie remains what he must be to Mr. Cohen: an enticing puzzlement, his faith a mystery.
If Aman is gradually accepted by the Singhs (and is he?), it seems to be only because they're so distracted by mishaps and gags.
"Gunday," directed by Ali Abbas Zafar, may be preposterous, but it's rarely dull. And when Mr. Khan and Ms. Chopra are on screen it's something more. It's downright enjoyable.
One reason "Chander Pahar" seems so plodding is that Mr. Mukherjee has a habit of telling us what he doesn't know how to show.
"Dhoom 2" had fun with the mechanics of crime and crime fighting. This movie can't be bothered.
Mr. Khan can be a subtle actor who uses his body eloquently, though not here.
"Paris Countdown" is a buddy movie with a downbeat heart.
The action sequences mostly have tension and punch, even if the movie is old-school long - 2 hours 41 minutes - and the plot doesn't bear too much scrutiny.
"I" is exuberant and unselfconscious but too cartoonish to engage your emotions.
"Hawaizaada" often fails to soar. Mr. Puri works hard, but the strain shows and so do the movie's seams.
These people's stories unfold in surprising ways, as does Ms. Honigmann's documentary, which mostly avoids the formulaic.
If you could separate spectacle from story, "Arjun" wouldn't be half bad.
A lavish 3-D pageant with the depth of a children's pop-up book.

movie_review_blurb: A dramatic life does not necessarily a dramatic film make.
