Avoiding flabby subplots, Mr. Dholakia keeps "Raees" taut and suspenseful, even at two and a half hours, though it probably has a song too many.
The movie, written and directed by Neeraj Pandey, is not hagiographic or overly obvious. Instead, it's something of a quiet muddle, with too many squandered or dramatically blurry scenes.
Mr. Roshan, an appealing dancer, works hard to twinkle his way into our affections and make Sarmar something more than a cardboard hero. He can't, but the effort is appreciated.
Mostly "Baaghi" is a fight movie, and a slightly dull one at that, overstuffed with boom-boom set pieces.
Even though "Kapoor & Sons" goes from lightly comic to more darkly dramatic to pretty overtly melodramatic, it never loses its lived-in quality or plunges into the absurd.

"Fitoor" doesn't get much political resonance out of its Kashmiri setting, though the wintry sadness of the first scenes has power. Nor does it get much resonance out of class differences between Noor and Firdaus.
Ms. Kongara seems to know the clichés of fighter movies and is mostly unembarrassed to embrace them. That keeps the film humming along, as does Mr. Madhavan, who grows in stature along with Adi.
The central pair of defiant lovers are never particularly convincing as convention-busters, nor are they as appealing as the rooms they inhabit or the clothes they wear.
With its full complement of lavishly produced song-and-dance numbers, its filmi heroes and villains, and a two-hour, 40-minute runtime, "Prem" hews closely to the old-style Bollywood formula.

"India's Daughter" is a portrait of a place and time. And for all of its horrors, the movie has a positive message, too: Out of tragedy - and this case is just one of many - can come galvanizing change.
Mr. Khan is this movie's best weapon. Playing a familiar character type, the world-weary detective, he gives a performance, full of small, sly details, that doesn't seem familiar at all.
With its light silent comedy, Mr. Wenders's film presents movie history as a meeting of the inventive and the inevitable - a playful lark.
movie_title: Trick of the Light (Die Gebrüder Skladanowsky) (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Ms. Geis wisely plants her camera in the rehearsal room, and mostly leaves it there.
As David's trainer tells him: "The world is cruel, master. It laughs at your pain." And it applauds your pain, too, especially the punishing physical kind. It's up to you to keep the tears flowing.
For much of its first half, Bombay Velvet hums with the kind of energy found in movies by the 1970s American directors Mr. Kashyap seems to admire. (Martin Scorsese is thanked in the head credits.)
Bhashkor is not your typical Bollywood papa, and "Piku," directed by Shoojit Sircar from a script by Juhi Chaturvedi, isn't a typical Hindi movie.

It irreverently normalizes a topic that has been virtually absent from screens in India (where gay sex is still technically illegal), and does so using contemporary Bollywood's best not-so-secret weapon: star power.
"How do middle-class people like us stand up for our country?" Byomkesh asks Ajit. The teasing answer: "We don't. We go to the movies."
Mr. Mehta has done something difficult. He has made a film of conviction that's neither plodding nor preachy.
"Besharam" is frequently crude, but it's also unusually clean in its plotting. And it has a kind of unblushing vitality that is especially strong in the dance numbers ...
The film can't sustain a tone, wavering between realism and Bollywood hokum.
It's something of a one-note groove, but Mr. Mitre knows how to play it.
It may be old-fashioned - love, family and grandfather's famous Khurana chicken win the day - yet it feels fresh.
Aging is probably the real theme here, but it's approached sidelong and has no punch. Still, only the nostalgia has any real conviction.
"That's What She Said," an unpleasant comedy about friendship, aims to be a female twist on the bromance.
Fast and mostly fun, the movie also seems compulsively too much, throwing everything it can think of at you, lest it fail to entertain.
The slick filmmaking - the movie has a glossy, Hollywood-ready feel that sometimes tips into the cutesy - works against its themes.
movie_title: La nouvelle guerre des boutons (War of the Buttons) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: More preachy than stirring; it hits its themes too squarely on the nose and hits them for about an hour too long.
We're left to imagine the hero's formative struggles and learn almost nothing about the history and distinctiveness of Salvador.
The filmmakers retain a touching faith that most Americans won't tolerate injustice when they know about it. This film is meant to teach them.
Pulpy but attenuated, "Heroine" tries to do too much: deliver an exposé of the back-stabbing film business while also drawing a portrait of a woman caught in its vice.
Against your will, you may even shed a tear.
The film world setting could be better exploited and Shanaya's jealousy made less mechanical, but "Raaz 3" delivers other goods ...
The movie, stuck like a scratched record, doesn't know what to make of this one point it compulsively and clumsily dramatizes.
This is an excellent story, and Ms. Draper tells it clearly and stylishly, teasing out the interesting angles and repercussions.
It shows us unhurried bits of daily life and lived-in faces but remains firmly on the outside, carefully making its slow study.
movie_title: Anhey gorhey da daan (Alms for a Blind Horse) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Tiger and Zoya both make good kung fu street fighters, but as spies they're unconvincing, and as lovers they're cookie-cutter bland.
For all its omissions and problems, "The Green Wave" communicates certain basic truths effectively: Many Iranians want their voices to be heard and their votes to count.
"It Is No Dream" satisfies neither as a movie nor as a history lesson.
movie_title: It Is No Dream: The Life of Theodor Herzl (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film's arguments about sustainability are convincing and hard to shake. And, the movie suggests, you - the sushi eater - can help: Crave it and enjoy it, but eat sushi responsibly.
Though studied and grating at times, "Drunkboat" does sustain a distinct, odd tone. Like its characters it's dreamily restless and prey to its own quixotic ideas.
It feels over-familiar, worthy of only the occasional grin.
[It] has a lovely, unforced quality.
"Corpo Celeste" often stumbles, along with its 12-year-old heroine, Marta (Yle Vianello).
Ridiculous and undeniable, it's a punchy cartoon, rightly confident of its power to entertain. Why resist?
Instead of pulsing with freewheeling energy, it sags under its earnest polemics.
By keeping its focus admirably tight, the sober and sobering Israeli documentary "The Law in These Parts" presents a devastating case against the occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
"Gayby" is too diffuse to have much pop when it comes to the topics at hand: love and friendship, and how unconventional modern permutations might help rewrite the script of romance.
[It] may sound like Sitcomland, but Mr. Mohan's sensibility - visually, comically, in terms of character - is more naturalistic, more Sundance. It's just not particularly sharp.
The movie chugs along for most of its 2 hours and 20 minutes searching for comedy and characters in a frantically overplotted story.
The images and voices are a mix of the curious, the compassionate, the condescending and worse.
"Somm," though an entree into a little-known world, rarely finds a second dimension.
Too often it calls to mind the much better "Delhi Belly," which had a genuinely madcap script and sharper things to say about being young, urban and Indian.
It's very much a Hindi film, but updated and delivered with conviction and style.

Mr. Kapoor and Mr. Shroff, stars of an earlier generation, are well cast and well matched. Where a '70s Hindi film might pit villagers against an evil landowner, "Aurangzeb" paints a more complex picture of villainy.
"Re-emerging" can be pedestrian as filmmaking, though it remains interesting as long as it remains in Nigeria.
[It] may not be fully satisfying as a documentary. But it has what any good movie needs: a star - the ever-game soprano Natalie Dessay.
The movie's message, delivered in song at the end, seems less like a credo than like an excuse: "Sometimes all you need to do is try."
A movie that, if never exactly dull, feels drained of the mythic juice that powers the book, which won the Booker Prize in 1981.
It's a remarkable story, even if "The Revolutionary," a no-frills documentary drawn from five years of interviews, isn't much of a movie.

In a better movie you might play along with contrived plot twists and fake obstacles, but watching "I Do," a movie with thin characters and a languorous pace, you find yourself talking back to the screen.
Leonie Gilmour was almost certainly unusual and unusually self-reliant. Too bad that the film that bears her name ultimately reduces her to the mother of her child.
Mr. Mortensen keeps you watching, even when the movie's storytelling underwhelms.

Mr. Zhang, whose wide-screen compositions have an unfussy elegance, mostly manages his balancing act. His measured style gives the film a steady-as-she-goes ballast even as it follows impulsive, unsettled lives.
A mix of gently outraged populism and low-powered romantic comedy, Vishal Bhardwaj's "Matru ki Bijlee ka Mandola" might have been better with a chunk lopped off its two-and-a-half-hour runtime.
It's dragged down by non-scene after non-scene, and filmmaking choices that don't earn their keep.
If only "Red Flag" were funnier and tighter and had a sharper idea about what it means to blur the lines between self-interrogation and self-absorption.
"Race 2," directed by Abbas-Mastan, has little to offer besides its loving gaze at wealth and flesh.
Mixes, not quite successfully, traditional Bollywood storytelling with something less conventional.
The filmmakers mix the playful and serious, with only occasional lapses.
A workaday Bollywood romance ...
As a director, Mr. Dolan has a freewheeling style, and he's self-dramatizing enough to want to call attention to it without being too much of a visual show-off.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Viagem ao Princípio do Mundo (Journey to the Beginning of the World)(Voyage to the Beginning) (1997)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
A quiet, no-nonsense film that is compelling and watchable despite its heavy politics.
Quote not available.
A gorgeous cough syrup hallucination -- the kind of beautiful, feverish dream to which you succumb while eardrum-piercingly high on over-the-counter cold medicine.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
movie_title: El Hechizo de un Sueño Eterno (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
movie_title: La Lengua de las Mariposas (Butterfly) (Butterfly Tongues) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the often-unappealing subject matter, however, the film remains compelling.
The film gives a glimpse into a land that is as far removed from Western society as any in the world.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Much of the dialogue - which should be champagne bubbly in a romantic comedy - is flat and murky.
Quote not available.
Although Kenneth Branagh's interpretation does much to make Shakespeare's play comprehensible, it ultimately fails to create any kind of enduring watchability.
Lacks sufficient dramatic thrust to captivate its audience beyond the first 30 minutes.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Despite the film's occasional goofy turns, by the end, chances are, you'll be rooting for the Ulam to work out that nifty little stick-rubbing trick for themselves.

movie_title: Jane White is Sick and Twisted (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Most of the actors struggle with the clunky dialogue and often look almost as uncomfortable delivering it as you'll feel sitting there watching them do so.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The themes of degradation, spiritual hollowness and abandonment are just not conveyed with enough freshness or subtlety to impress.
Although the sight of a shirtless Elvis wrestling a native warrior is fascinating enough, there are few surprises in the sequence of events.

Herzl's approach might not be great for one's cholesterol or blood pressure, but it brings up an intriguing idea, one that isn't talked about often...: Maybe it would be better to be fat and happy than thin and miserable.
For all Oceans does to please the eyes and ears, it does nothing to engage the brain.
The material is so relentlessly dark -- suicide, rape, eating disorders and repression all have a home here -- that the film will satisfy only Iranian history buffs and devoted Neshat fans.
There's a reason nobody made a movie about the 1983 bust of Soviet spies with the code name "Farewell" until now: It's too bloody complicated.
An uneven film that, by trying to satisfy parents with political drama and older children with a love story, leaves both parties wanting.
The Concert was so unfunny, I had to consult IMDB.com to make sure that it was indeed listed as a comedy.
What kind of kid will be able to appreciate this serious plot, which involves investors pulling out of a land-development deal and a scary, knife-wielding witch?
movie_title: Mia et le Migou (Mia and the Migoo) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If director Eran Riklis's intention is to show the blossoming humanity, so to speak, of a human resources manager, the transformation is much too subtle to work.
Raises intriguing questions about our culture of online humiliation and the real-life destruction it can leave in its wake.
An educational, eye-opening, zero bells-and-whistles report on the state of western society.
The Ritual is a cracking horror movie and one of those rare examples where the film improves on the source material (a 2008 novel by Adam Nevill).

As Katy was seen doubling over in pain as she forced the last few tears to fall, clutching the wall for support as she gasped for breath wearing a rotating sparkly bra, I was shocked to discover that my own cheeks were wet.
Ang Lee's astonishing adaptation of Yann Martel's fantastical bestseller makes it hard to believe how anyone dubbed Life of Pi 'unfilmable'.
Haseena Parkar could have been a real thriller had it been serious about telling serious story. But it tries to add too much masala and style to story and serves up absolutely no substance.
movie_title: Haseena (Haseena: The Queen Of Mumbai)(haseena Parkar) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are the biggest highlight and the one and only reason why Bhoomi works out, as much as it does.
Patel Ki Punjabi Shaadi is one weary film about Indian communities and their closed mind-sets. Definitely not up to the times.
Funny, relevant and deeply gratifying, Newton is a veritable modern classic.
No high drama, no outrageous adventure, just plain vanilla everyday life happenings. Not a lot of fun.
We know cause based films are the norm right now and maybe the idea behind the film was prison reform. It's heart was in the right place but everything else wasn't...
Simran is a fine and fresh comedy. It does more to prove the leading lady's talent rather than entertain. But end of the day, it's a clean and happy film.
What's absolutely refreshing is Arjun Rampal's performance and transformation as Arun Gawli.
The result is a glorious piece of fear and terror. A worthy adaptation to the works of the genius of horror.
It has a unique theme and it delivers all its sex charged punches with aplomb. This one's hard-core fun.
The screenplay and execution literally steal defeat from the jaws of victory.
Good music, solid performances, relevant story, Qaidi Band has everything a film for young India would need.
Jacqueline handles the comedy, glamour and dancing. While Darshan Kumar plays the bad boy with elan. Smart writing and slick execution save this fickle film.

The film's packed with almost every style of filmmaking. It's interesting because it's so unique. The editing and the cinematography of CRD is world class. The strength of filmmaking technique makes sure the film looks and feels spectacular.
Like all his film's, this one has a homebrew flavour of Soderbergh's backyard of anti-studio film development. That makes it both fresh and fantastic.
This is popcorn entertainment at its mindless best.
At one point, Bank Chor feels like an Abbas Mustan thriller, what with double cross, deceit and murder becoming the mainstay of the story. But the witty comedy keeps the thrill of the concept alive.
Writer Lee Hall and director Stephen Frears drop the ball with this royal escapade.
The Founder and it's recreation of the '50s and '60s American culture and capitalism is insightful and enriching.
The great part about Spider-Man is that it manages to be a seamless part of the current Marvel universe and yet, etch out a wonderfully snazzy world for a new superhero.
Mom is a heavy duty, darkly dramatic film that doesn't mince its ideas. It's a story full of brutality and shock. The dramatic punches are what make this film such a gratifying experience.
Its obnoxious title aside, Edgar Wright's Baby Driver is possibly the heist, action film that modern pop culture was waiting for.
Sadly, the film doesn't quite do justice to its own potential and that definitely squanders the efforts of the actors.
This is a sweet little film alright, but the emotional inconsistencies just don't iron out. It's a classic case of what could've been a great film, settles for much less.
Like countless romantic comedies before, this film just feels like another romantic film made on a template. Perfectly average, nothing special.
Dobaara: See Your Evil just doesn't manage to conjure up any scares.
[Chris Pine's] chemistry with [Gal] Gadot is sparkling. But this is film is all about Wonder Woman. And Gadot looks like she was born to bring this legend to life on the big screen.
A good film for those who believe in being hopelessly romantic.
Charlie Hunnam plays Fawcett with great command and emotional depth. Whether it's the physical transformations or the emotional ups and downs, he gets the soul of the character bang on.
The Lego Ninjago Movie is the third movie based on the lego franchise and it's the weakest one yet.
Tu Hai Mera Sunday is a decent watch. It's definitely a better story than its trite title. A feel-good film especially for younger citizens of India's big booming cities.
movie_title: You Are My Sunday (Tu Hai Mera Sunday) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Blade Runner 2049 is director Dennis Villeneuve's best film yet. It's an audio-visual masterclass that will be best experienced in IMAX.
American Made is funny, insightful, controversial and spunky all at once.
This one's not an explosion of gastronomy but it is a slow and flavoured broth of genuine emotions.
The eerie long silences and the mysterious silhouettes add a punch to the film. And once the hauntings start, this movie gives even The Conjuring a run for its money.
It's audacious, brilliant and definitely a super powered comedy.
The one and only reason why Atomic Blonde becomes a sinfully good action movie is Charlize Theron's supremely choreographed action sequences. She throws the kitchen sink at this film.
While the movie does get a lot of things right, it just lacks a little conviction in presenting its powerful ideas.
Fast & Furious 8 is pure madcap mayhem.
For the casual viewer, Noor serves up a refreshing new story. One that has a solid heart of gold.

Aftermath could've been about so much more. It could've been a search for faith and hope. It could've been a story of forgiveness and second chances. But what it could never be, is a film that redirects the career of a fading action star.
When it matters the most, the climax of the story, director Ashtar Sayed and his team drop the ball.
While it doesn't have the same panoramic adventure of its predecessor, it does make up with grand scale and precise execution. This movie is worth the hype.

Sarkar 3 has the right ideas but it makes a complete mess of its political themes by trying to be quirky for no reason. Had RGV just stuck to intensity and grit, this would've been a thrilling comeback for the maverick filmmaker.
Guardians Of The Galaxy Vol 2 builds on the franchise with everything that makes this Marvel offering unique. But most of all it's the music that works wonders here.
While King Arthur is not Guy Ritchie gold, it is an entertaining film that serves up the right amount of thrills, spills and wit.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This movie has its moments. Scenes featuring classic numbers like Mere sapno ki rani from Aradhana and Meri pyaari bindu from Padosan are superb.
Alien Covenant is a slick film no doubt. Some of its set pieces have a genuine terror feel too. But it's the woefully conceived characters that really spoil the party for this franchise booster.
This film is warm, fuzzy and yet thought provoking. It's a film every new parent needs to watch. It's definitely one of the best of the year.
Sadly, the film makes a total meal put of original concept. Its not even half as good as the book its based on.
With a generous runtime of almost 2.5 hours, Kung-fu Yoga does outstay its welcome.
It isn't director Onir's best film. But it is a compelling look at human beings and their complex range of emotions and relationships.
The very idea of ghost in a metallic shell talks of a surreal irony. A deep concept that vanishes in Hollywood's ambition to carve out a franchise.
It's not Dhanush's best film, but it is one solid entertainer that benefits from the crackling chemistry between its leads.
If you get the vein of this layered comedy, you'll have a monster of a ball for sure.
This is an intimate affair with the scarier prospects of a lonesome life in a big city. Insightful and effective, Trapped is a must watch for all movie buffs.
Young kids and their adult parents are the only people who'll be able to find some value to The Emoji Movie. Anyone else will probably just smash their smartphone in a bout of raging frustration.

Shanker Raman's Gurgaon has thrills, twists and a dark storyline that can give you goosebumps. At times it's a little too slow for comfort, but even then the visual detail and visceral content of this thriller make it a very enriching experience.
Toilet - Ek Prem Katha is a solid entertainer with a strong social message.
Raag Desh recreates an important chapter of Indian history. Best part is, it does so with great detail and authenticity.

Indu Sarkar is no satire or subliminal piece on the history of Indian politics. It takes too many cinematic liberties, but thankfully its focus on the strong female lead lends it credibility and keeps the jingoism curbed.
While The Black Prince could've been a compelling real-life inspired drama, it strictly manages to stay average fare.
All the goodness of this slick looking film dies the moment it resorts to the regular tropes of reincarnation formula. Its like watching a 2017 film that was written in 3 days in 1960.
movie_title: Ek Haseena Thi Ek Deewana Tha (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Mixing horror with comedy allows director Rohit Sherry to bring a new element to his style of filmmaking.
In the same vein as the movie's excessive themes, John Wick: Chapter 2 should be called a modern action classic.
This is a once in a lifetime movie.
While the actors give it their best shot, Rangoon just isn't able to tell its story with consistency.
The film does have a generous amount of gore and splatter. But the whole blood soaked approach is what makes this movie such a dark and fascinating experience.
The only reason someone could sit through this movie is for the pretty visuals and the somewhat average performances of the cast. But even that will require insane levels of patience.

The usual tropes of masala movies like the spunky music and the slick clothes etc add no value to this movie. What does make sense is the fact that it takes run of the mill romance and turns it into a quirky and very entertaining experience.
Beauty & The Beast is every bit as good and joyous as its original inspiration. A must watch for sure.
Phillauri is truly a fun film. For romance enthusiasts, this movies got everything. For the casual movie goer, it's got the right amount of humour.
There are the usual tropes of generation divide, bhartiya sanskar and punjabi weddings which doesn't create any excitement at all.
If you like to have fun and you don't mind entertainment over cerebral arguments, Farah Khan's Happy New Year is worth your time.
The underlying critique of war and focus on survival and hope is what makes this film so great.
Jai Ho Demcracy is reasonably shot, well-edited and generally put together nicely. But its screenplay hasn't been too well thought out.
Barfi! is that rare film that can make you smile and make you cry in the same scene. Its technical brilliance is only outdone by its emotional complexity and depth.
Had Gabbar Is Back had stuck to the nitty-gritties of its original it could've been a decent watch. But it strays from the path grossly.
[Shetty] has an eye for intricate design. He pays attention to crafting scenes and characters. Couple that with Ajay Devgn's unfailing intensity and you have the tour de force Singham Returns.
Piku is Shoojit Sircar's film. It's his way of celebrating forgotten cinema by Bengali greats.
If any film deserves to be a hit in 2015, it's this brilliant piece of cinema.
The one most prominent feature of Action Jackson is its incoherence.
Nothing earth shattering here. No promise of rewriting cinema history. This movie is just a pleasant no frills family entertainer.
[Sriram Raghavan's] fan boy exuberance isn't enough to save an overcooked pot-boiler.
A certified visual delight.
It's a solid biopic drama one that doesn't unnecessarily glorify its subject.
This is still one of the best films you'll watch this year.
Qissa is a film about broken minds, social dysfunctions and alternate sexuality in pre-partition India. It has all the trappings of a great art film. But it's served with nonchalant experimentation.
movie_title: Qissa: The Ghost Is A Lonely Traveller (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Not only is it a sequel better than its predecessor, it's a movie that engages you and captivates you like no other.
A brainless romp.
The director makes sure he serves everything required to make a Salman Khan fan happy.
Maggie is a novel idea. In certain places its shot beautifully as well. But the film is too indulgent and deliberate.
It's two-and-a-half hours of relentless comedy, action and drama. Most of it requires clinical skills of suspension of disbelief. But believe you me, in the end it's well worth the effort.
This film packs enough Sallu and Kat charisma to make it worth the price of its ticket.
An exhilirating and engaging experience.
This humanization of sorts, of the God of cricket, is a rare event. That's reason enough to watch and relish this remarkable film on a man who's inspired billions in the last 28 years.
The narrative flaws and love story clichés are only too obvious. They do great disservice to the cast.

It's good to watch a woman who's more level headed than her better half. Who can smoke a cigarette just for the sake of having one. Who can drive a car better than any tom, dick or harry in Delhi. And one who doesn't take things lying down.
Raanjhanaa is one of the best written films in a while. And one of the best films you'll watch in a while too.
What's sadder than the sorry story is that Hrithik Roshan is condemned to be better than the movies he acts in.
Nawaz singlehandedly is responsible for making this film fresh, funny, quirky and sublime.
Good God! Narcissism was never this mainstream.
Arjun's done a decent job, but sadly the director chose the most worn out story in cinema.
It's well-made though and extremely likeable. There's more of the Sonam Kapoor we saw in Khoobsurat. And that's a guarantee for popcorn entertainment.
If all this don't please you, nothing will.
It may be flawed but it's just too beautiful.
A film that ignores all its promise and steamrolls its way to being mediocre.
A moving argument to why we love a phenomenon called Amitabh Bachchan.
A fitting tribute.
Jab Tak Hai Jaan (JTHJ) is Yash Chopra's last film as director and it's a film rich in philosophy, poetic love and honest emotions.
It's the perfect exotic weekend getaway.
It's a fun film for kids, young adults as well as grownups that actually grew up wide-eyed at the prospect of a gigantic safari with the dinosaurs.
To make matters worse, you have some of the most juvenile dialogue on offer.
This one is definitely an upgrade on its original.
There are too many things happening all at once.
Fan is Shah Rukh Khan's best effort since Chak De! India.
Civil War has all the trappings to sway your experience and make you feel like you've watched the best superhero movie of your life.
Here the action is just down to humans and aliens exchanging green laser firefights.
Shorgul tries to tell a tale of merit. But the methods it employs to tell its story are so jaded, you just lose your faith in the film.
With everything that's wrong with The Legend Of Tarzan, the movie on a whole still works because it all looks so polished and slick.
When it comes to entertainment, Sultan packs a solid punch.
Pet lovers especially will enjoy this kooky concoction of cute and sass.
It takes Rajnikanth's presence to make Kabali an entertaining movie. Without him, this would've been a good looking but very forgettable film.
This is a must watch.
It is the greatest story ever told in Indian cinema.
Lipstick Under My Burkha is both relevant and relatable. The best part is, all four women and their stories and setups are perfectly real.
Solid performances, great music and solid writing, director Advait Chandan couldn't have asked for a better setup for a debut film.
The general sense of dread and nervous tension keeps this sexually charged film alive.
Watch this if you must for Aishwarya Rai Bachchan who's still in top form. Pity her comeback film doesn't measure up to her efforts.
If Casino Royale changed the dynamics of Bond, Skyfall's cemented them.
The fresh new faces and a brisk runtime of 131 minutes make Hero a breezy entertainer.
Phantom is slightly lacking in cinematic intelligence and guile.
It's an infectious experience
The story is as senseless as the name of the film.
It's certainly a better Terminator film than the previous two. But it's also not in the same league as Terminator 2: Judgement Day.
Subhash Kapoor's film is well-made. But it's also severely flawed.
The relentless action mixed with some potent 3D makes for some jaw dropping viewing.
[Priyanka Chopra's] performance is focused and intense. The way she picks up the North Eastern accent, the way she picks fights with boys, the way she picks up the nuances of boxing are masterful.
Bahubali is truly an epic experience.
While the intentions are noble, the execution of Jagga Jasoos' history driven pro-patriotic and world peace preaching narrative is a bit too jarry.
You have the enviable cast, the powerful premise and yet the end result isn't as spectacular as it should've been.
A layered and sublime tale about life, death and beyond.
The film suffers from a busload of bad direction.
So the story grips you. But the director doesn't do any favours to the film.
Director Karan Anshuman's clever eye for detail and in-jokes are left in the lurch. This one could've been such a riot.
Brothers offers a whole new experience to MMA action. Hindi audiences will enjoy the novelty. But all said and done, this should've been done with a lot more finesse.
It's rare to see such transcendence in a film. And that's exactly why this should be watched and cherished by every movie buff out there.
The problem with Manjhi is that it oversimplifies the story to the point where it becomes a run-of-the-mill good versus bad saga.
This film is a total package.
SRK's bravado dialogue delivery has some great stand out moments.
Even by small film standards Budhia Singh has a remarkable amount of cinematic finesse.
Moonlight is not just sublime cinema, this is pure art.
The only good thing about this frivolous romance is its leading man and his good looks.
It's the perfect flavour of Pineapple Express.
The new film is like a cheap Chinese clone. Its slick to look at, but once you experience it first hand; you realize it is in essence a cheap knock-off.
Remarkably, from the very first shot of young Pete and his parents driving into the country side, Pete's Dragon has a very Steven Spielberg like quality.
Mothers from middle class families are the perfect and only target audience for this film. For everyone else there's a better bad movie called Stop Or My Mom Will Shoot!
Star Trek: Beyond is a film worth marvelling at.
If you are a seasoned movie buff, chances are you'll be bored to death.
Underplay and restraint are the strengths of Carol. This is a film that stays clear of dramatisation. It kills you softly.
There's plenty to cheer about and nothing really to reflect upon or celebrate. Save for the fact that, Bay had good intentions while making this movie based on real events.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a crazy ride to a world where imagination fuels an entertainment effort like never before.
Gerard Butler: Look David, from one Scot to another, I'm really glad you gave us this idea. But maybe the Brits can produce a film like this for themselves.

Rob Friedman: What is that supposed to be? Matt Sazama: Well sir. This is all original. We've just borrowed inspirations. Alex told us to refer to Mr Butler's DVDs but Burk got this bright idea at the video store.
In parts it's almost like a thriller, save for Disney's musical touches and Rudyard Kipling's moral additions.
The movie works. It tells an important story and it does make a meal out of the subject.
Apart from the pretty faces and the challenges of raising kids, there's nothing really that would connect with any of us.
This film is exactly like any other Jason Statham movie you may have seen before.
Bottom line: should you watch Triple 9? No! Is it a slick thriller? Yes, but only in its looks.
This Chinese-American goulash with a sprinkling of Mongolian and Russian elements is just all over the place.
It seems to try too hard. And in the process of trying to be too dramatic it makes a meal of its themes.
It's just a middle-of-the-road offering where seeing an actor look like the mirror image of Veerappan catches your fancy for a few fleeting moments.
The erotic nature of their conversations and their ability to retain their spirit through all adversity makes this film a true blue winner.
The plot doesn't quite throw up as much moving drama as it should.
The Shallows is a taut thriller.
Well acted, well intentioned and inspiringly brave, Pink is the film that can shake up feudal mindsets in India.
You can easily compare Don't Breathe to thriller horror classics like Psycho, Old Boy and Vertigo.
Even with it's middle of the road approach, this edgy film on sexual flings and intimate relationships has the right ideas. Watch this and you'll be bound to giving it a nod of recognition.
While good intentions cannot be totally ignored, they're not merely enough by themselves to make a difference.
Ahalya is definitely a thrill a second ride
At times the movie doesn't feel too well thought out. The execution really let's down the writing.
A classic case of wasted opportunity.
That spectacle is right in front of your eyes. And it's fabulous.
movie_title: The Making of Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [Randeep Hooda's] French accent, his casual body language the piercing confidence in his eyes is spectacular. This is the kind of performance that you'd expect from a seasoned Hollywood pro.
Wedding Pullav is an undercooked film, lacking the right kind of spice and flavour.
Only Hate Story 3 isn't as relevant to modern society as the genre it aspires to be part of. The film is not only jaded, it's downright pointless.
Even with its slightly convenient climax, Sully makes a strong comment on its subject.
After the efforts of the actors its director Mira Nair's deft handling of the subject that makes Queen Of Katwe such a delightful and genuine film.

Watching an underdog win International sprints in sepia tone is reminiscent of Bhaag Milkha Bhaag. But this movie has much more emotional depth and deftness than the Indian biopic. If you enjoy films and sports, this is a must watch.
If you're an accompanying adult, be rest assured, there's plenty of chuckles in it for you too. It's a real egg-citing film.

There's no catchy music, there's very little to hold your interest in terms of story and/or creative concept. There is some meaty dialogue though. And that helps supporting actors like Ram Kapoor, Ila Arun and Vir Das help bring home the bacon.

For each of these cringe worthy moments, Aashiqui 2 also has honest and effective scenes of passion and drama. The thought behind this film is perfect. But the execution tries too hard to put it in line with the original.
With The Last Jedi, Rian Johnson's done to the Star Wars franchise what Joss Whedon had done for Marvel with The Avengers. Disney and Lucasfilm have another solid franchise base in the offing now.
The heady mixture of an international looking action film and the regular tropes of Hindi cinema make it a pleasing watch.
This movie subliminally depicts its provocative themes in the most tasteful manner. This is a must watch.
The one reason Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children works wonders is Tim Burton's direction and some well crafted CGI.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mukkabaaz isn't just a well-executed film. Its major strength comes from its super performances.

Without the policing and the comprises, Padmavati would've been a lot better film. But Padmaavat isn't anything less. This film is rich in detail, still tells a compelling story with grit and gumption.
Maze Runner was a franchise that started off with a fresh idea in the first film. But it huffed and puffed its way to a climax that in all fairness, is nothing short of a massive let down.
The thrills and the CGI look half-baked. It's not what you expect from a Jackie Chan movie.
It had the spunk that we've seen before in Subhash Kapoor's Jolly LLB movies. But all of that promise is laid to waste with uninspiring execution.
movie_title: Kuldip Patwal: I Didn't Do It! (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Great action, palpable tension, a solid performance and even a heist film twist ending; Den Of Thieves delivers a lot for your average action flick.

For young lovers and those obsessed with good morning, good night and all sorts of wishes on WhatsApp, Kuchh Bheega Alfaaz has a lot to offer. Despite the slow build-up, it manages to entertain with ease.
Hate Story 4 serves up a lot of twists and turns but it's all too predictable. Most of the clever story reveals are let down by the fact that there's just too much erotica on offer.
Lost in translation would be an understatement.
The climax is gripping. It's a pity that the rest of the movie didn't have the same resolve.
Watch this and you may not be moved but you'll definitely be entertained.
Goliyon Ki Raasleela Ram-leela is an illogical love tale dressed up in opulence. A classic case of looks can be deceptive.
Ekkees Toppon Ki Salaami isn't the worst film ever made. It's got its moments. But when it comes to cinematic quality it has no leg to stand on. It's just too erratic to merit any credibility.
So are the Turtles boring? Hell no! They're still as cool as ever. It's just that their adventures have become pointless.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Now You See Me 2 is a desperate attempt to pull a franchise out of thin air. But this glitzy Hollywood hoodwink is nothing more than a slavish pull of wool over the audiences eyes.
If you're one of those who're petrified by a scary movie, be prepared to scream in horror.
The 3D, the sense of adventure and the striking visuals are all just frills trying to hard sell and underwhelming story.
A tad too long and tad too inconsistent, the only respectability that Free State Of Jones retains is thanks to Matthew McConaughey's performance.
The reason any of this works is because of one man. Ryan Reynolds is in the form of his life.
Ittefaq is a solid modern whodunit. It looks as slick as any Hollywood production. Even with its mistakes, the crime mystery manages to impress with its logical and clinical writing.
Thor Ragnarok gets the comic book vibe bang on. Its cool, its funny and most importantly its the right amount of outrageous. Its one of Marvel's best.

When SMZA talks about the dowry system the inequality towards women in civil services and general working opportunities, it feels like a mature and relevant story. But the treatment is so lackluster that it relegates the movie to Indian soap opera status

The best moments of Qarib Qarib Singlle are the most understated and sublime ones. There are no 'jeene marne ki qasamein' no drama, just a casual, simple and very refreshing romance that says a lot without much effort
Justice League is just about the most drab and lacklustre superhero epic ever made.

There's a lot to like about Tumhari Sulu. Not just Vidya Balan's stupendous talent, but the heart-warming romance, the crazy dreams of a housewife and the dramatic moments involving the young son are all fantastic.
While Murder On The Orient Express does have its heart in the right place, it doesn't quite get the game of sleuth as good as it should.
Ajji is a bit of a mixed bag. The film has some really powerful moments. But the problematic treatment and the art-heavy approach keep it from being the ideal thriller.
Even the spicy and spirited performances by Parineeti and Aditya fail to satiate one's appetite for real drama. Even Sajid Wajid's tasteful music goes to sheer waste.
Jolly LLB's screenplay maybe predictable, end of the day it's inspired by the real-life case of Sanjeev Nanda. But what the story lacks in terms of surprise, the cast makes up with its performances
Quick take: Absurdly bad!
The writing and the direction on this film are so convoluted the actors have nothing left, but to curl up and wait for the inevitable.
It mostly makes you sit and wonder if you were cheated of your time and money.
It has a great idea, noble intent, a stellar cast comprising of Naseeruddin Shah, Arshad Warsi and Divya Dutta, yet this film squanders its promise with aplomb.

While it's not as well conceived as the first film, Jolly LLB 2 benefits from the powerhouse performances of Akshay Kumar and Annu Kapoor. The actors rise above the script and make this court room brawl a very satisfying experience.
[Hrithik Roshan's] perfectly nuanced performance is the reason you'll enjoy the thrills of Kaabil.
Its social relevance aside, that the film manages to sneak in humour, slice of life and drama into such a complex and hard hitting subject is its true triumph.

It's all well done. The production, the sound, the action is all top notch. But the writing is King of the game in a film. The technique is merely a pawn. You can sacrifice the pawns but not the King.
This film is a thundering body slam of honest emotions and sheer hard work.
It has a deep desire to be erotic and funny but for all its progressive ambitions, it tells a jaded story.
Even though the story feels all too familiar, the updated packaging adds a new appeal. The quintessential love triangle still has entertainment value.
John Abraham should be renamed the desi Hulk and director Abhinay Deo can well be Bollywood's answer to Luc Besson
The performances save it from the limitations of its writing and execution. Rock On 2 is nevertheless a bittersweet symphony.
Ventilator is one of the most honest and emotional films of the year. It's a Marathi film worth treasuring. It's an Indian film worth celebrating.
If you like genuine thrills you'd have to look away. This one's just for gags.
The very fact that this film successfully portrays love and its various facets with such deftness and control is its true success
Anyone watching this film will have to settle for its intentions alone. Everything else in this melodramatic overdose is genuinely embarrassing.
If you enjoy Guy Ritchie's films, Saat Uchakkey will please you to the bone
Mohammed Azharuddin's much anticipated biopic is an underwhelming, face-saving exercise where one of the hottest sporting stories is relegated to formulaic heroism and courtroom antics.
The stand out performance is by [Tamannaah Bhatia] who switches between the dual nature of her role with ease.
... like an old school, middle-of-the-road movie, Sarbjit wants to spell it out for the viewer. In doing so, it makes a meal out of its subject.
Despite a good lead pair the movie makes a complete meal out of its subject. Movies that qualify for the so-bad-it's-good genre are fun, but that's definitely not a compliment.
This one's a gem of a film. One that takes an already spectacular story and turns it into an absolute sublime experience. Those multiple Oscar nominations are much deserved.
Dr Strange provides an enriching and exhilarating experience.
With crisper editing and less melodrama, Shivaay could've been the best of the year. But the 'more is less' approach just doesn't work out.
Mohenjo Daro is a well-made film, just not very well thought out.
This film has some fantastic moments. Some soul searching philosophy and some heart crushing realities on offer. Dear Zindagi is a feel good film. An experience that will make you feel alive.
Despite its flaws, PRDP manages to entertain you. It's long yes, and most of its story is almost too sentimental. But then it works.
It's definitely one of the year's best.
Despite the glaring flaws and some really cacophonous music, the message of Madaari is resoundingly strong.
It's classic Hindi movie fluff, updated with modern filmmaking styles.
While it's certainly not the worst film ever made, it's also not a film you can recommend with ease.
The entire cast looks like they're victims of bad direction and worse writing.
Whether you like the frills or not, there's no denying that RR2 is a film that haunts you.
Director Abhishek Kapoor could've done a lot more with this film. The love story between his leads should have been a lot more intense. But in the end the film turns out to be a shallow affair.

It doesn't over dramatize the story. It takes an emotional and mature stance about its subject. It makes you believe in the power of human beings. That ordinary people can make a difference if they try.
It proves that the happily ever after notion may be overused and old, but it still gets the job done.
Director Ribhu Dasgupta's second movie is just about as good as taut thrillers can be. There's a directorial control and finesse that make this film engaging and well worth a watch.
It does feel a bit underwhelming at first, but if you give it a thought, the conclusion is a fair and logical end to the premise.
The problem with a film like Mastizaade is not that it's overloaded with sex. The problem is that the sexual content isn't just regressive, it's plain stupid.
Staying true to surreal legends, Rakeysh Omprakash Mehra's Mirzya, inspired by the Mirza-Sahiban saga is a deeply vague but extremely beautiful picture.
It's feisty, boisterous and spirited just like any revered sporting champion.
Dilwale is the quintessential popcorn flick. It's colorful, bright and entertaining.
Ironically, it has a story that tries to ward off mediocrity in everyday life, and yet the film only manages to evoke mixed reactions.

Debut films are always a bit rough around the edges, but Titli is a little too blunt and all too intentionally. Yes his film shows some relevant themes, but you can't be so serious and morose about your subject.
I Love New Year is a romantic comedy that's neither too funny nor too alluringly mushy. It's just a posh looking two-hour long feature film. Very forgettable fare.
[Yea Toh Two Much Ho Gayaa's] jaded writing and lacklustre direction relegate it to forgettable status.
movie_title: Yea Toh Two Much Ho Gayaa (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It had the raw potential of a unique and innovative film. But the lackof focussed direction leaves it high and dry.
With so many confused aspirations, the film becomes a garish hotchpotch, an unpalatable goulash.

Watching the three lead characters go from teen years to college life to quarter life crisis does become a bit too tedious and tiring. But if you don't mind a hotch potch of masala movie trappings, Love Day does have the audacity to engage and entertain.
The ennui of the subject and the film leaves the audience with a major downer too.

There are two good things about Beiimaan Love, one's Sunny Leone and the other is the film's music. Rest of the movie is jaded, overtly sentimental and trying too hard to be a contemporary love story.
Wah Taj is an amateur film at best. But It's also an honest and relevant jab at corruption in veil of progress.

One moment it's a love story and another it's a shoddy horror movie. Things get so random at one point; you feel you're actually watching a parody and not a horror film taking itself all too seriously.
Director Mike Mitchell loads the movie with countless pop culture references that make the story telling both cute and cool.
It doesn't have great dialogue or memorable set pieces, but within the confines of its setup it comes up with enough madness to please the average idiot-comedy buff
[A] weepy romance that's tedious and long drawn.
[Sushant Singh Rajput] lives the part and makes Dhoni come alive.
The dramatic scenes are hotchpotch. But when the action turns on, it grips you and it keeps on the edge of your seat.
It's like Kapoor & Sons recreates a reality and it does so with deftness and authenticity.
The underdog story is a proven winner in cinema, but this movie just misses the right note.

Apart from the writing, there are issues with the editing of Ki And Ka. The gaping holes in quality in these two departments can't be saved, even by the peppy music of Mithoon, Meet Bros. Anjjan and Ilaiyaraaja.
The feeling of watching Island City can be surreal, profound and absurd all at the same time. That's how the movie is designed.
You can't sell a 100-year-old idea with futuristic frills. That just doesn't add up.
Rustom is not a 100 per cent authentic, it's not the most intelligible film either, but within the confines of a commercial movie, it does offer a compelling argument.
Despite the best efforts of its cast, and some really exotic locations on offer, Fever makes a meal out of its premise.
You can't convey such serious messages about environmental issues with such juvenile ideas. If you do, you end up looking like a super powered embarrassment.
It may seem like an exercise in women's rights, but AR Murugadoss' approach to make things entertaining and detailed makes this movie worth a watch. This one's all about girl power.

Animated movies especially, suffer the greatest drop in quality with sequels. But Kung Fu Panda 3 is a definite exception to the rule. The third instalment is just as quirky, funny and engaging as the first one.
The Man From Nowhere is a decent action film from Korea, made back in 2010. Rocky Handsome is just a cheap knock off, made in India.
The emotions of the movie are honest and that's it's strength. The reason these emotions comes across as authentic is because an experienced cast employs masterful underplay.
There are a few rough edges on this gritty drama, but a stellar performance by Randeep Hooda smoothens any jaggedness
The music is perfect and colourful. The dialogue is soul stirring in the film. In the big bad world of big ticket releases this little film with a big heart has all the right ideas.

The film is constantly trying to take a path less travelled; unfortunately it's not the right path. In the process of being different, the movie becomes incoherent and eventually ends up being commonplace.

You got bad guys, girl, dog, hero, forest, hills, rivers, ravines, guns, random Mallu men with fancy goggles. It's the perfect setting for Indian Rambo. Only it's foiled by a screenplay that was written by a sloth, a snail and a tortoise. It's sloooooow.

All said and done, if you want to gain a perspective on what went wrong in Armstrong's professional pursuits, this film is worth a watch. But if you have plans of discovering more about the man himself, we'll just have to wait for a more solid reboot.
Watch it for thrills; watch it with a pro-feminist stance.
